questions.question: What are the symptoms of migraine?
questions.answer: Common symptoms of migraine include severe throbbing headache (usually on one side), nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, visual disturbances (aura), and sometimes tingling sensations. Migraines can last from 4 hours to 3 days.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of stroke?
questions.answer: Stroke symptoms include sudden numbness or weakness in face, arm or leg (especially on one side), confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech, difficulty seeing, loss of balance or coordination, severe headache with no known cause. Remember FAST: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease?
questions.answer: Early symptoms include memory loss affecting daily activities, difficulty completing familiar tasks, confusion with time or place, trouble understanding visual images, problems with speaking or writing, misplacing things, decreased judgment, withdrawal from social activities, and changes in mood or personality.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Parkinson's disease?
questions.answer: Main symptoms include tremor (shaking, usually starting in hands), slow movement (bradykinesia), muscle stiffness, impaired balance and coordination, changes in speech, writing changes, loss of automatic movements like blinking, and rigid facial expressions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of epilepsy?
questions.answer: Seizure symptoms vary but may include temporary confusion, staring spells, uncontrollable jerking movements, loss of consciousness, unusual sensations (tingling, strange smells or tastes), sudden fear or anxiety, and temporary loss of awareness or confusion.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of brain tumor?
questions.answer: Brain tumor symptoms include persistent headaches, seizures, vision problems, hearing problems, balance and coordination difficulties, personality changes, memory problems, nausea or vomiting, weakness or numbness in limbs, and difficulty with speech.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of meningitis?
questions.answer: Meningitis symptoms include sudden high fever, severe headache, stiff neck, nausea and vomiting, confusion, sensitivity to light, drowsiness, skin rash (in some cases), and difficulty waking up. This is a medical emergency requiring immediate attention.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of multiple sclerosis?
questions.answer: Multiple sclerosis symptoms vary but commonly include numbness or weakness in limbs, tingling sensations, electric-shock sensations with neck movements, lack of coordination, vision problems, dizziness, fatigue, slurred speech, and bladder problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of brain aneurysm?
questions.answer: Unruptured aneurysm may have no symptoms. Ruptured aneurysm symptoms include sudden severe headache (worst headache of life), nausea, vomiting, stiff neck, blurred or double vision, sensitivity to light, seizure, drooping eyelid, loss of consciousness, and confusion.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dementia?
questions.answer: Dementia symptoms include memory loss, difficulty communicating, confusion, disorientation, personality changes, depression, anxiety, inappropriate behavior, paranoia, agitation, hallucinations, and difficulty with complex tasks and planning.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of tension headache?
questions.answer: Tension headache symptoms include dull, aching head pain, tightness or pressure across forehead or sides and back of head, tenderness in scalp, neck and shoulder muscles, and sometimes mild sensitivity to light or sound.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of concussion?
questions.answer: Concussion symptoms include headache, confusion, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, sensitivity to light and noise, balance problems, memory problems, difficulty concentrating, and fatigue. Some symptoms may appear immediately, others may develop hours later.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of depression?
questions.answer: Depression symptoms include persistent sad or empty mood, loss of interest in activities, changes in appetite or weight, sleep disturbances, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, and thoughts of death or suicide.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anxiety disorder?
questions.answer: Anxiety symptoms include excessive worry, restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle tension, sleep problems, rapid heartbeat, sweating, trembling, shortness of breath, and panic attacks.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of insomnia?
questions.answer: Insomnia symptoms include difficulty falling asleep, waking up frequently during night, waking up too early, not feeling rested after sleep, daytime fatigue, irritability, difficulty concentrating, and increased errors or accidents.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cluster headache?
questions.answer: Cluster headache symptoms include severe pain around or behind one eye, pain occurring in patterns (clusters), watery eye, red eye, stuffy or runny nose on affected side, sweating, pale or flushed face, and restlessness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Bell's palsy?
questions.answer: Bell's palsy symptoms include sudden weakness or paralysis on one side of face, drooping mouth, drooling, difficulty closing eye, loss of taste, pain around jaw or behind ear, increased sensitivity to sound, and difficulty with facial expressions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of traumatic brain injury?
questions.answer: Traumatic brain injury symptoms include headache, confusion, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, sleep problems, sensitivity to light and sound, memory problems, mood changes, and loss of consciousness (in severe cases).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of encephalitis?
questions.answer: Encephalitis symptoms include headache, fever, confusion, seizures, stiff neck, sensitivity to light, drowsiness, loss of consciousness, hallucinations, agitation, personality changes, and weakness or paralysis in certain areas.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Huntington's disease?
questions.answer: Huntington's disease symptoms include involuntary jerking movements (chorea), muscle rigidity, slow movements, difficulty swallowing, speech problems, cognitive decline, difficulty organizing tasks, lack of impulse control, and mood changes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis)?
questions.answer: ALS symptoms include muscle weakness, muscle twitching, difficulty speaking or swallowing, muscle cramps, stiffness in arms and legs, difficulty holding head up, slurred speech, and difficulty breathing (in later stages).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of narcolepsy?
questions.answer: Narcolepsy symptoms include excessive daytime sleepiness, sudden loss of muscle tone (cataplexy), sleep paralysis, hallucinations when falling asleep or waking up, and disrupted nighttime sleep.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sleep apnea?
questions.answer: Sleep apnea symptoms include loud snoring, gasping for air during sleep, morning headache, excessive daytime sleepiness, difficulty concentrating, irritability, dry mouth upon waking, and observed pauses in breathing during sleep.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of vertigo?
questions.answer: Vertigo symptoms include spinning sensation, dizziness, loss of balance, nausea, vomiting, sweating, abnormal eye movements, headache, and difficulty standing or walking.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neuropathy?
questions.answer: Neuropathy symptoms include numbness or tingling in hands and feet, sharp or burning pain, sensitivity to touch, muscle weakness, lack of coordination, paralysis (if motor nerves affected), and heat intolerance.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of brain hemorrhage?
questions.answer: Brain hemorrhage symptoms include sudden severe headache, weakness or numbness, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, vision changes, loss of balance, confusion, loss of consciousness, nausea, vomiting, and seizures.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cerebral palsy?
questions.answer: Cerebral palsy symptoms include abnormal muscle tone, lack of coordination, tremors, involuntary movements, difficulty walking, speech problems, swallowing difficulties, developmental delays, seizures, and learning disabilities.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hydrocephalus?
questions.answer: Hydrocephalus symptoms vary by age. In infants: enlarged head, bulging fontanel, vomiting, sleepiness. In older children and adults: headache, nausea, vomiting, vision problems, balance difficulties, cognitive problems, urinary incontinence.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Tourette syndrome?
questions.answer: Tourette syndrome symptoms include motor tics (eye blinking, head jerking, shoulder shrugging) and vocal tics (throat clearing, grunting, repeating words). Tics may be simple or complex and vary in frequency and severity.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of trigeminal neuralgia?
questions.answer: Trigeminal neuralgia symptoms include sudden, severe facial pain (like electric shock), pain triggered by touching face, chewing, speaking, or brushing teeth, pain episodes lasting seconds to minutes, pain on one side of face.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of restless leg syndrome?
questions.answer: Restless leg syndrome symptoms include uncomfortable sensations in legs (crawling, tingling, pulling), irresistible urge to move legs, symptoms worse at rest, symptoms worse in evening or night, temporary relief with movement.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder)?
questions.answer: PTSD symptoms include intrusive memories, flashbacks, nightmares, severe anxiety, avoidance of reminders, negative changes in thinking and mood, hyperarousal, irritability, difficulty sleeping, and difficulty concentrating.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder)?
questions.answer: OCD symptoms include obsessive thoughts (fear of contamination, need for order), compulsive behaviors (excessive cleaning, checking, counting), significant distress, time-consuming rituals, and interference with daily activities.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of schizophrenia?
questions.answer: Schizophrenia symptoms include hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech, disorganized behavior, reduced emotional expression, social withdrawal, lack of motivation, and impaired cognitive function.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of bipolar disorder?
questions.answer: Bipolar disorder symptoms include mood swings between mania (elevated mood, increased energy, impulsive behavior) and depression (sad mood, loss of interest, fatigue), changes in sleep patterns, and difficulty with daily functioning.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of autism spectrum disorder?
questions.answer: Autism symptoms include difficulty with social communication, repetitive behaviors, restricted interests, sensitivity to sensory input, difficulty understanding emotions, preference for routine, and delayed language development.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ADHD (Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder)?
questions.answer: ADHD symptoms include inattention (difficulty focusing, easily distracted, forgetfulness), hyperactivity (excessive talking, fidgeting, inability to sit still), impulsivity (interrupting, acting without thinking), and difficulty organizing tasks.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of brain abscess?
questions.answer: Brain abscess symptoms include headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, confusion, seizures, weakness or numbness on one side, vision changes, speech problems, and stiff neck.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of transient ischemic attack (TIA)?
questions.answer: TIA symptoms are similar to stroke but temporary: sudden weakness or numbness, difficulty speaking, vision problems, dizziness, loss of balance. Symptoms typically last less than 5 minutes but can last up to 24 hours.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome?
questions.answer: Guillain-Barré symptoms include tingling in fingers and toes, weakness starting in legs and spreading upward, difficulty walking, difficulty with facial movements, difficulty swallowing, severe pain, rapid heart rate, and breathing difficulties.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of myasthenia gravis?
questions.answer: Myasthenia gravis symptoms include muscle weakness that worsens with activity, drooping eyelids, double vision, difficulty swallowing, difficulty speaking, facial weakness, difficulty breathing, and arm or leg weakness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Chiari malformation?
questions.answer: Chiari malformation symptoms include headache (especially after coughing or straining), neck pain, dizziness, balance problems, muscle weakness, numbness or tingling, vision problems, difficulty swallowing, and ringing in ears.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome?
questions.answer: Chronic fatigue syndrome symptoms include severe fatigue not improved by rest, post-exertional malaise, unrefreshing sleep, difficulty concentrating, memory problems, muscle pain, joint pain, headaches, and sore throat.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of fibromyalgia?
questions.answer: Fibromyalgia symptoms include widespread muscle pain, fatigue, sleep problems, morning stiffness, headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, numbness or tingling, sensitivity to temperature, and difficulty concentrating (fibro fog).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dystonia?
questions.answer: Dystonia symptoms include involuntary muscle contractions, twisting or repetitive movements, abnormal postures, tremor, difficulty speaking or swallowing (if affects throat), and symptoms that may worsen with stress or fatigue.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of essential tremor?
questions.answer: Essential tremor symptoms include rhythmic shaking (usually in hands), tremor during movement, tremor that worsens with stress or fatigue, tremor affecting voice or head, difficulty with fine motor tasks.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of temporal arteritis?
questions.answer: Temporal arteritis symptoms include severe headache (usually in temples), scalp tenderness, jaw pain when chewing, vision problems or sudden vision loss, fever, fatigue, weight loss, and shoulder or hip pain.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of normal pressure hydrocephalus?
questions.answer: Normal pressure hydrocephalus symptoms include difficulty walking (shuffling gait), urinary urgency or incontinence, memory problems, difficulty concentrating, and slowed thinking.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of progressive supranuclear palsy?
questions.answer: Progressive supranuclear palsy symptoms include difficulty with balance and walking, stiffness, difficulty moving eyes (especially looking down), speech problems, swallowing difficulties, personality changes, and cognitive impairment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease?
questions.answer: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease symptoms include rapidly progressive dementia, personality changes, memory loss, impaired judgment, vision problems, involuntary movements, muscle stiffness, difficulty speaking, and difficulty swallowing.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Lewy body dementia?
questions.answer: Lewy body dementia symptoms include visual hallucinations, cognitive fluctuations, Parkinson-like movement symptoms, sleep disturbances, autonomic dysfunction, depression, and attention problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of vascular dementia?
questions.answer: Vascular dementia symptoms include confusion, difficulty concentrating, difficulty organizing thoughts, slowed thinking, memory problems, restlessness, agitation, depression, and difficulty walking.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of frontotemporal dementia?
questions.answer: Frontotemporal dementia symptoms include personality changes, socially inappropriate behavior, lack of empathy, compulsive behaviors, changes in eating habits, speech difficulties, and movement problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of moyamoya disease?
questions.answer: Moyamoya disease symptoms include recurrent strokes or TIAs, headaches, seizures, cognitive decline, movement disorders, vision problems, speech difficulties, and weakness or numbness on one side of body.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of syringomyelia?
questions.answer: Syringomyelia symptoms include muscle weakness, loss of reflexes, loss of sensitivity to pain and temperature, stiffness in back and legs, pain in neck and arms, scoliosis, and bowel and bladder problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of spinal cord injury?
questions.answer: Spinal cord injury symptoms include loss of movement, loss of sensation, loss of bowel or bladder control, exaggerated reflexes or spasms, pain or stinging sensation, difficulty breathing, and loss of sexual function.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cavernous malformation?
questions.answer: Cavernous malformation symptoms may include seizures, headaches, neurological deficits (weakness, numbness, vision problems), hemorrhage symptoms if bleeding occurs, and some people may have no symptoms.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of arteriovenous malformation (AVM)?
questions.answer: AVM symptoms include seizures, headaches, progressive neurological symptoms, pulsing sound in head, vision problems, weakness or numbness, difficulty speaking, confusion, and bleeding symptoms if rupture occurs.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of pseudotumor cerebri?
questions.answer: Pseudotumor cerebri symptoms include severe headaches, vision problems (blurring, double vision, vision loss), pulsatile tinnitus (whooshing sound), shoulder or neck pain, and brief vision blackouts.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of acoustic neuroma?
questions.answer: Acoustic neuroma symptoms include hearing loss on one side, ringing in ear, dizziness, loss of balance, facial numbness or weakness, difficulty swallowing, and headache.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of pituitary tumor?
questions.answer: Pituitary tumor symptoms include vision problems, headaches, hormone imbalances (irregular periods, erectile dysfunction, breast milk production), fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and unexplained weight changes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of glioblastoma?
questions.answer: Glioblastoma symptoms include persistent headaches, seizures, nausea and vomiting, memory loss, personality changes, weakness on one side of body, speech difficulties, and vision problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of meningioma?
questions.answer: Meningioma symptoms include headaches, vision problems, hearing loss, memory loss, seizures, weakness in arms or legs, numbness, difficulty speaking, and personality changes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of oligodendroglioma?
questions.answer: Oligodendroglioma symptoms include seizures, headaches, weakness or paralysis on one side, speech problems, personality changes, nausea and vomiting, and vision changes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of medulloblastoma?
questions.answer: Medulloblastoma symptoms include headache, nausea and vomiting (especially in morning), balance and coordination problems, double vision, difficulty walking, fatigue, and irritability.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ependymoma?
questions.answer: Ependymoma symptoms include headache, nausea and vomiting, neck pain, balance problems, vision problems, seizures, irritability in children, and developmental delays.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurocysticercosis?
questions.answer: Neurocysticercosis symptoms include seizures, headaches, confusion, difficulty maintaining balance, swelling of brain, hydrocephalus symptoms, vision problems, and meningitis symptoms.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cerebral vasculitis?
questions.answer: Cerebral vasculitis symptoms include severe headaches, stroke-like symptoms, seizures, confusion, behavioral changes, cognitive difficulties, vision problems, and speech difficulties.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Miller Fisher syndrome?
questions.answer: Miller Fisher syndrome symptoms include difficulty with eye movements (ophthalmoplegia), unsteady gait (ataxia), loss of reflexes, facial weakness, difficulty swallowing, and double vision.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cauda equina syndrome?
questions.answer: Cauda equina syndrome symptoms include severe low back pain, saddle anesthesia (numbness in groin/buttocks), bladder dysfunction, bowel incontinence, severe or progressive weakness in legs, and loss of reflexes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of locked-in syndrome?
questions.answer: Locked-in syndrome symptoms include inability to move or speak (except vertical eye movements and blinking), full consciousness and cognition, ability to communicate through eye movements, quadriplegia, and difficulty swallowing.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of akinetic mutism?
questions.answer: Akinetic mutism symptoms include lack of spontaneous movement, lack of speech, appearing awake but not responsive, can track objects with eyes, can sometimes respond to commands, and preserved consciousness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of central pontine myelinolysis?
questions.answer: Central pontine myelinolysis symptoms include difficulty speaking (dysarthria), difficulty swallowing, weakness in arms and legs, confusion, hallucinations, impaired consciousness, and locked-in syndrome in severe cases.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Wilson's disease?
questions.answer: Wilson's disease symptoms include fatigue, jaundice, abdominal swelling, tremors, difficulty walking, muscle stiffness, speech problems, behavioral changes, and kayser-fleischer rings in eyes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurosarcoidosis?
questions.answer: Neurosarcoidosis symptoms include headache, vision problems, hearing loss, facial weakness (Bell's palsy), seizures, confusion, memory problems, hallucinations, mood changes, and weakness or numbness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of primary progressive aphasia?
questions.answer: Primary progressive aphasia symptoms include difficulty finding words, difficulty understanding speech, making grammar errors, difficulty reading and writing, slow speech, and relatively preserved memory initially.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of corticobasal degeneration?
questions.answer: Corticobasal degeneration symptoms include rigidity and stiffness on one side, difficulty with coordinated movements, jerky movements (myoclonus), alien limb syndrome, speech difficulties, swallowing problems, and cognitive changes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of fatal familial insomnia?
questions.answer: Fatal familial insomnia symptoms include progressive insomnia, panic attacks, hallucinations, rapid weight loss, dementia, inability to regulate body temperature, autonomic dysfunction, and eventually coma.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Rasmussen's encephalitis?
questions.answer: Rasmussen's encephalitis symptoms include frequent seizures, progressive weakness on one side of body, loss of cognitive skills, inflammation of brain, hemiparesis, speech problems, and vision problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of stiff person syndrome?
questions.answer: Stiff person syndrome symptoms include progressive muscle stiffness and rigidity, muscle spasms triggered by noise or touch, heightened sensitivity to stimuli, difficulty walking, chronic pain, and anxiety.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Lambert-Eaton syndrome?
questions.answer: Lambert-Eaton syndrome symptoms include muscle weakness (especially in legs and hips), difficulty walking, difficulty swallowing, drooping eyelids, dry mouth, erectile dysfunction, and weakness that improves briefly with movement.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neuromyelitis optica?
questions.answer: Neuromyelitis optica symptoms include vision loss in one or both eyes, weakness or paralysis in legs or arms, painful spasms, loss of sensation, uncontrollable vomiting and hiccups, and bladder or bowel problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cerebellar ataxia?
questions.answer: Cerebellar ataxia symptoms include poor coordination, unsteady walk, tendency to stumble, difficulty with fine motor tasks, changes in speech, involuntary eye movements, and difficulty swallowing.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of spinocerebellar ataxia?
questions.answer: Spinocerebellar ataxia symptoms include progressive lack of coordination, difficulty walking, poor hand-eye coordination, abnormal eye movements, difficulty speaking, difficulty swallowing, and cognitive impairment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Friedreich's ataxia?
questions.answer: Friedreich's ataxia symptoms include difficulty walking, muscle weakness, speech problems, involuntary eye movements, scoliosis, heart disease, diabetes, loss of reflexes in legs, and loss of sensation in extremities.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cerebellar degeneration?
questions.answer: Cerebellar degeneration symptoms include loss of coordination, impaired balance, difficulty with precise movements, tremor during movement, slurred speech, difficulty swallowing, abnormal eye movements, and cognitive changes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of olivopontocerebellar atrophy?
questions.answer: Olivopontocerebellar atrophy symptoms include difficulty walking, poor coordination, speech difficulties, difficulty swallowing, involuntary eye movements, muscle rigidity, tremor, and autonomic dysfunction.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of primary lateral sclerosis?
questions.answer: Primary lateral sclerosis symptoms include weakness in legs, stiffness in legs and lower body, slow and clumsy hand movements, difficulty with balance, speech problems, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and exaggerated reflexes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of progressive muscular atrophy?
questions.answer: Progressive muscular atrophy symptoms include muscle weakness starting in hands and arms, muscle wasting, muscle cramps, twitching, fatigue, difficulty with fine motor tasks, and progression to other muscle groups.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Kennedy's disease?
questions.answer: Kennedy's disease symptoms include muscle weakness and wasting (especially in arms and legs), muscle cramps, tremor, difficulty swallowing, speech problems, enlarged breasts in men, and testicular atrophy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Isaac's syndrome?
questions.answer: Isaac's syndrome symptoms include continuous muscle twitching (myokymia), muscle cramps, muscle stiffness, excessive sweating, slowed movements, and difficulty relaxing muscles.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of multifocal motor neuropathy?
questions.answer: Multifocal motor neuropathy symptoms include weakness in hands and arms (usually asymmetric), muscle cramps, muscle twitching, muscle wasting, dropped objects, and difficulty with fine motor tasks.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy?
questions.answer: Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy symptoms include weakness in legs and arms, loss of reflexes, numbness or tingling, difficulty walking, difficulty with coordination, fatigue, and pain in some cases.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of brachial plexus injury?
questions.answer: Brachial plexus injury symptoms include severe pain in shoulder or arm, weakness or inability to move shoulder or arm, lack of muscle control in arm or hand, numbness or loss of sensation, and paralysis in severe cases.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome?
questions.answer: Carpal tunnel syndrome symptoms include numbness or tingling in thumb and fingers (except little finger), pain in hand and arm, weakness in hand, difficulty gripping objects, and symptoms worse at night.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ulnar nerve entrapment?
questions.answer: Ulnar nerve entrapment symptoms include numbness or tingling in ring and little fingers, weakness in hand, difficulty with finger coordination, pain in elbow or hand, and claw-like deformity in advanced cases.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of radial nerve palsy?
questions.answer: Radial nerve palsy symptoms include wrist drop (inability to extend wrist), difficulty extending fingers, numbness or tingling on back of hand, weakness in arm, and difficulty gripping objects.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of peroneal nerve injury?
questions.answer: Peroneal nerve injury symptoms include foot drop (difficulty lifting front of foot), numbness or tingling on top of foot, weakness in ankle and foot, difficulty walking, and slapping gait.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sciatic nerve pain?
questions.answer: Sciatic nerve pain symptoms include pain radiating from lower back down leg, sharp or burning pain, numbness or tingling in leg, muscle weakness in leg or foot, difficulty moving leg or foot, and pain worse with sitting.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of diabetic neuropathy?
questions.answer: Diabetic neuropathy symptoms include numbness or tingling in hands and feet, burning pain, sharp pain, sensitivity to touch, muscle weakness, loss of reflexes, loss of balance, digestive problems, and bladder problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of peripheral neuropathy?
questions.answer: Peripheral neuropathy symptoms include numbness or reduced sensation in hands and feet, tingling or burning sensation, sharp or jabbing pain, sensitivity to touch, lack of coordination, muscle weakness, and paralysis if motor nerves are affected.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of autonomic neuropathy?
questions.answer: Autonomic neuropathy symptoms include dizziness when standing, bladder problems, sexual dysfunction, difficulty digesting food, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, abnormal sweating, and difficulty regulating body temperature.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of focal neuropathy?
questions.answer: Focal neuropathy symptoms include sudden weakness in one nerve or nerve group, pain, numbness or tingling in specific area, double vision, Bell's palsy, pain behind one eye, chest or abdominal pain, and pain in thigh.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of proximal neuropathy?
questions.answer: Proximal neuropathy symptoms include severe pain in hip, thigh or buttock, weakness in thigh muscles, difficulty rising from sitting position, abdominal swelling, weight loss, and pain usually on one side of body.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of post-concussion syndrome?
questions.answer: Post-concussion syndrome symptoms include persistent headaches, dizziness, fatigue, irritability, anxiety, difficulty concentrating, memory problems, sleep disturbances, sensitivity to light and noise, and ringing in ears lasting weeks to months.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of chronic traumatic encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Chronic traumatic encephalopathy symptoms include memory loss, confusion, impaired judgment, impulse control problems, aggression, depression, anxiety, suicidal thoughts, progressive dementia, and Parkinson-like symptoms.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of subdural hematoma?
questions.answer: Subdural hematoma symptoms include headache, confusion, slurred speech, weakness or numbness on one side, vision changes, seizures, personality changes, loss of consciousness, and difficulty walking.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of epidural hematoma?
questions.answer: Epidural hematoma symptoms include initial loss of consciousness, brief lucid interval, rapid deterioration of consciousness, severe headache, confusion, vomiting, seizures, weakness on one side, and dilated pupil.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.answer: Subarachnoid hemorrhage symptoms include sudden severe thunderclap headache, nausea and vomiting, stiff neck, vision changes, confusion, drowsiness, seizures, loss of consciousness, and sensitivity to light.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of intracerebral hemorrhage?
questions.answer: Intracerebral hemorrhage symptoms include sudden severe headache, weakness on one side, difficulty speaking, vision problems, loss of balance, nausea and vomiting, decreased consciousness, confusion, and seizures.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ischemic stroke?
questions.answer: Ischemic stroke symptoms include sudden numbness or weakness in face, arm or leg (especially one side), confusion, trouble speaking or understanding, vision problems in one or both eyes, difficulty walking, dizziness, and severe headache.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hemorrhagic stroke?
questions.answer: Hemorrhagic stroke symptoms include sudden severe headache, weakness on one side, nausea and vomiting, decreased alertness, vision changes, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, difficulty swallowing, and loss of balance.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cerebral edema?
questions.answer: Cerebral edema symptoms include headache, nausea and vomiting, dizziness, memory loss, confusion, vision problems, difficulty speaking, seizures, loss of consciousness, and neck stiffness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of increased intracranial pressure?
questions.answer: Increased intracranial pressure symptoms include severe headache, nausea and vomiting, vision changes (blurred or double vision), confusion, drowsiness, seizures, irregular breathing, elevated blood pressure, and decreased consciousness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of brain stem stroke?
questions.answer: Brain stem stroke symptoms include vertigo, dizziness, double vision, slurred speech, difficulty swallowing, weakness on one or both sides, numbness on one or both sides, loss of coordination, and altered consciousness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cerebellar stroke?
questions.answer: Cerebellar stroke symptoms include inability to walk, loss of coordination, dizziness, severe headache (especially back of head), nausea and vomiting, difficulty with precise movements, and abnormal eye movements.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of lacunar stroke?
questions.answer: Lacunar stroke symptoms include pure motor weakness on one side, pure sensory loss on one side, weakness and clumsiness on one side, or combination of weakness and sensory loss without other symptoms like vision or speech problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of carotid artery stenosis?
questions.answer: Carotid artery stenosis may have no symptoms or may cause TIA or stroke symptoms including sudden weakness or numbness, difficulty speaking, vision loss in one eye, dizziness, and loss of balance.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of vertebrobasilar insufficiency?
questions.answer: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency symptoms include dizziness, vertigo, double vision, difficulty speaking, difficulty swallowing, weakness on both sides, numbness on both sides, loss of coordination, and drop attacks.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome?
questions.answer: Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome symptoms include sudden severe thunderclap headaches, sensitivity to light, nausea, vomiting, confusion, vision changes, seizures, and sometimes stroke symptoms.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cerebral amyloid angiopathy?
questions.answer: Cerebral amyloid angiopathy symptoms include recurrent brain hemorrhages, cognitive decline, memory problems, seizures, headaches, stroke symptoms, and progressive dementia in some cases.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Binswanger's disease?
questions.answer: Binswanger's disease symptoms include progressive cognitive decline, memory problems, personality changes, mood changes, urinary problems, difficulty walking, falls, slowed movements, and vascular dementia symptoms.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of CADASIL?
questions.answer: CADASIL symptoms include recurrent strokes or TIAs (typically starting in mid-adulthood), migraines with aura, mood disturbances, cognitive decline, seizures, and progressive dementia.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sinus thrombosis?
questions.answer: Sinus thrombosis symptoms include severe headache, vision problems, seizures, stroke symptoms, nausea and vomiting, weakness on one side, confusion, and difficulty speaking.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of venous sinus thrombosis?
questions.answer: Venous sinus thrombosis symptoms include headache (often severe and progressive), vision problems, seizures, focal neurological deficits, altered consciousness, papilledema, and stroke-like symptoms.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Wernicke's encephalopathy symptoms include confusion, loss of muscle coordination, vision problems (double vision, abnormal eye movements), hypothermia, low blood pressure, and memory problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Korsakoff syndrome?
questions.answer: Korsakoff syndrome symptoms include severe memory impairment (especially forming new memories), confabulation (making up information), lack of insight, apathy, difficulty with abstract thinking, and relatively preserved other cognitive functions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Hepatic encephalopathy symptoms include confusion, altered consciousness, personality changes, mood changes, poor judgment, difficulty concentrating, hand tremor (asterixis), musty odor to breath, and in severe cases coma.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hypoxic brain injury?
questions.answer: Hypoxic brain injury symptoms include confusion, difficulty concentrating, memory problems, changes in personality, difficulty with coordination, seizures, vision problems, altered consciousness, and cognitive impairment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anoxic brain injury?
questions.answer: Anoxic brain injury symptoms include confusion, memory loss, personality changes, difficulty with coordination, vision problems, seizures, movement disorders, persistent vegetative state, or varying degrees of cognitive impairment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of toxic encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Toxic encephalopathy symptoms include confusion, memory problems, difficulty concentrating, personality changes, mood changes, headache, fatigue, tremor, vision problems, and cognitive impairment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of metabolic encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Metabolic encephalopathy symptoms include confusion, altered consciousness, lethargy, agitation, tremor, asterixis (hand flapping), seizures, difficulty concentrating, and changes in breathing pattern.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hyponatremic encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Hyponatremic encephalopathy symptoms include headache, nausea and vomiting, confusion, seizures, decreased consciousness, muscle weakness, muscle cramps, restlessness, and in severe cases coma.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hypernatremic encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Hypernatremic encephalopathy symptoms include irritability, lethargy, confusion, seizures, muscle twitching, increased reflexes, altered consciousness, weakness, and in severe cases coma.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of uremic encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Uremic encephalopathy symptoms include confusion, decreased alertness, fatigue, tremor, asterixis, seizures, muscle twitching, difficulty concentrating, memory problems, and altered consciousness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of diabetic coma?
questions.answer: Diabetic coma symptoms include confusion, weakness, nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain, rapid breathing, fruity breath odor, dry mouth, extreme thirst, decreased consciousness progressing to coma.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hypoglycemic encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Hypoglycemic encephalopathy symptoms include confusion, sweating, shakiness, rapid heartbeat, anxiety, irritability, hunger, blurred vision, weakness, seizures, and loss of consciousness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of mitochondrial disease?
questions.answer: Mitochondrial disease symptoms include muscle weakness, loss of coordination, seizures, vision and hearing loss, developmental delays, heart disease, stroke-like episodes, diabetes, and gastrointestinal problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Leigh syndrome?
questions.answer: Leigh syndrome symptoms include loss of previously acquired skills, loss of appetite, vomiting, seizures, muscle weakness, breathing problems, vision problems, heart disease, and developmental regression.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of MELAS syndrome?
questions.answer: MELAS syndrome symptoms include stroke-like episodes, seizures, headaches, muscle weakness, exercise intolerance, hearing loss, diabetes, short stature, and recurrent vomiting.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of MERRF syndrome?
questions.answer: MERRF syndrome symptoms include myoclonus (muscle jerking), seizures, ataxia, muscle weakness, hearing loss, short stature, exercise intolerance, dementia, and heart problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Kearns-Sayre syndrome?
questions.answer: Kearns-Sayre syndrome symptoms include progressive external ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle paralysis), pigmentary retinopathy, heart conduction defects, muscle weakness, hearing loss, and endocrine problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of adrenoleukodystrophy?
questions.answer: Adrenoleukodystrophy symptoms include behavioral changes, poor memory, vision loss, seizures, difficulty speaking, difficulty swallowing, difficulty walking, stiff muscles, paralysis, and adrenal insufficiency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of metachromatic leukodystrophy?
questions.answer: Metachromatic leukodystrophy symptoms include difficulty walking, frequent falls, loss of coordination, muscle rigidity, seizures, difficulty speaking, difficulty swallowing, vision loss, and cognitive decline.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Krabbe disease?
questions.answer: Krabbe disease symptoms include irritability, unexplained fevers, muscle stiffness, difficulty feeding, vomiting, seizures, vision loss, hearing loss, developmental delays, and loss of motor skills.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Canavan disease?
questions.answer: Canavan disease symptoms include poor head control, enlarged head, developmental delays, difficulty swallowing, seizures, vision problems, loss of previously acquired skills, and muscle weakness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Alexander disease?
questions.answer: Alexander disease symptoms include enlarged head, seizures, stiffness in arms and legs, developmental delays, difficulty swallowing, difficulty with coordination, and intellectual disability.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease?
questions.answer: Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease symptoms include nystagmus (rapid eye movements), delayed motor development, muscle rigidity, tremor, ataxia, cognitive impairment, and gradual loss of motor skills.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Tay-Sachs disease?
questions.answer: Tay-Sachs disease symptoms include loss of motor skills, decreased eye contact, exaggerated startle response, cherry red spot in retina, seizures, vision and hearing loss, paralysis, and intellectual disability.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Gaucher disease?
questions.answer: Gaucher disease symptoms (type 3 with neurological involvement) include eye movement abnormalities, seizures, brain damage, muscle rigidity, enlarged liver and spleen, bone problems, and cognitive impairment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Niemann-Pick disease?
questions.answer: Niemann-Pick disease symptoms include loss of motor skills, difficulty feeding, enlarged liver and spleen, cherry red spot in eye, developmental delays, muscle weakness, seizures, and cognitive decline.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Fabry disease?
questions.answer: Fabry disease symptoms include burning pain in hands and feet, reduced sweating, cloudiness of cornea, hearing loss, heart problems, kidney disease, gastrointestinal problems, and stroke.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of mucopolysaccharidosis?
questions.answer: Mucopolysaccharidosis symptoms include coarse facial features, enlarged head, short stature, skeletal abnormalities, joint stiffness, heart disease, hearing loss, vision problems, and developmental delays.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of phenylketonuria?
questions.answer: Phenylketonuria symptoms (if untreated) include intellectual disability, developmental delays, behavioral problems, seizures, tremor, hyperactivity, skin rashes, musty odor, and lighter skin and hair.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of maple syrup urine disease?
questions.answer: Maple syrup urine disease symptoms include poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, sweet-smelling urine, developmental delays, seizures, and in severe cases coma.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of homocystinuria?
questions.answer: Homocystinuria symptoms include intellectual disability, seizures, lens dislocation, severe nearsightedness, blood clots, skeletal abnormalities, osteoporosis, and tall thin build.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of urea cycle disorder?
questions.answer: Urea cycle disorder symptoms include vomiting, lethargy, confusion, irritability, refusal to eat, abnormal breathing, seizures, developmental delays, intellectual disability, and in severe cases coma.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of organic acidemia?
questions.answer: Organic acidemia symptoms include poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, seizures, developmental delays, weak muscle tone, abnormal movements, metabolic acidosis, and in severe cases coma.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Rett syndrome?
questions.answer: Rett syndrome symptoms include loss of purposeful hand use, loss of spoken language, gait abnormalities, repetitive hand movements, breathing problems, seizures, scoliosis, and severe cognitive impairment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Angelman syndrome?
questions.answer: Angelman syndrome symptoms include developmental delays, intellectual disability, speech impairment, movement and balance problems, seizures, frequent laughter and smiling, excitable personality, and sleep problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome?
questions.answer: Prader-Willi syndrome symptoms include poor muscle tone, feeding difficulties in infancy, insatiable appetite later, obesity, intellectual disability, behavioral problems, short stature, and small hands and feet.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of fragile X syndrome?
questions.answer: Fragile X syndrome symptoms include intellectual disability, developmental delays, social and behavioral problems, anxiety, hyperactivity, attention problems, autistic behaviors, seizures, and characteristic facial features.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of tuberous sclerosis?
questions.answer: Tuberous sclerosis symptoms include seizures, skin abnormalities (facial angiofibromas), intellectual disability, autism, benign tumors in brain and other organs, kidney problems, and heart problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurofibromatosis type 1?
questions.answer: Neurofibromatosis type 1 symptoms include café-au-lait spots, freckling in armpits or groin, neurofibromas (tumors), Lisch nodules in eyes, bone abnormalities, learning disabilities, and larger head size.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurofibromatosis type 2?
questions.answer: Neurofibromatosis type 2 symptoms include hearing loss, ringing in ears, balance problems, facial weakness, vision problems, numbness and weakness in extremities, and development of benign tumors.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of von Hippel-Lindau disease?
questions.answer: Von Hippel-Lindau disease symptoms include headaches, balance and coordination problems, dizziness, weakness, vision problems, high blood pressure, and various tumors in brain, spinal cord, kidneys, and other organs.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Sturge-Weber syndrome?
questions.answer: Sturge-Weber syndrome symptoms include port-wine stain birthmark on face, seizures, glaucoma, weakness on one side of body, developmental delays, intellectual disability, and headaches.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ataxia-telangiectasia?
questions.answer: Ataxia-telangiectasia symptoms include progressive difficulty walking, poor coordination, dilated blood vessels in eyes and skin, slurred speech, difficulty swallowing, frequent infections, delayed growth, and increased cancer risk.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Huntington's disease chorea?
questions.answer: Huntington's disease chorea symptoms include involuntary jerky movements, difficulty swallowing, slurred speech, difficulty with balance and coordination, cognitive decline, mood changes, and behavioral problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of benign essential blepharospasm?
questions.answer: Benign essential blepharospasm symptoms include increased blinking, involuntary closure of eyelids, eye irritation, sensitivity to light, difficulty keeping eyes open, and symptoms worsen with stress or fatigue.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hemifacial spasm?
questions.answer: Hemifacial spasm symptoms include involuntary twitching on one side of face, starting around eye and spreading to mouth, symptoms worsen with stress, difficulty with vision during spasms, and possible aching behind ear.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of writer's cramp?
questions.answer: Writer's cramp symptoms include difficulty holding pen, hand cramping or pain when writing, tremor in hand while writing, abnormal posturing of hand, and symptoms specific to writing task.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of musician's dystonia?
questions.answer: Musician's dystonia symptoms include loss of fine motor control when playing instrument, cramping or pain in affected muscles, involuntary movements during playing, and difficulty performing previously mastered techniques.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of spasmodic dysphonia?
questions.answer: Spasmodic dysphonia symptoms include strained or strangled voice quality, breaks in voice, effort required to speak, tremulous voice, voice that cuts in and out, and difficulty being understood.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cervical dystonia?
questions.answer: Cervical dystonia symptoms include head turning to one side, head tilting, head pulling forward or backward, neck pain, muscle spasms in neck, tremor, and symptoms may worsen with stress.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of oromandibular dystonia?
questions.answer: Oromandibular dystonia symptoms include difficulty opening or closing mouth, jaw deviation, tongue protrusion, difficulty speaking, difficulty chewing and swallowing, and facial grimacing.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of meige syndrome?
questions.answer: Meige syndrome symptoms include involuntary eye closure (blepharospasm), involuntary facial and jaw movements, difficulty speaking, difficulty swallowing, tongue protrusion, and sensitivity to light.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of tardive dyskinesia?
questions.answer: Tardive dyskinesia symptoms include involuntary facial movements (grimacing, tongue protrusion, lip smacking), rapid eye blinking, involuntary movements of limbs, difficulty swallowing, and breathing irregularities.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of chorea?
questions.answer: Chorea symptoms include involuntary jerky movements, dance-like movements, movements that flow from one body part to another, difficulty with voluntary movements, restlessness, and difficulty with balance and walking.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of athetosis?
questions.answer: Athetosis symptoms include slow, writhing involuntary movements, movements especially in hands and feet, difficulty maintaining posture, abnormal positioning of limbs, and difficulty with speech if face affected.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ballismus?
questions.answer: Ballismus symptoms include violent flinging movements of limbs, movements usually on one side (hemiballismus), large amplitude movements, continuous movements, difficulty with voluntary control, and fatigue.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of myoclonus?
questions.answer: Myoclonus symptoms include sudden brief muscle jerks, movements that may affect any part of body, positive myoclonus (muscle contraction) or negative myoclonus (muscle relaxation), and varying severity and frequency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of tics?
questions.answer: Tics symptoms include sudden, brief, repetitive movements or sounds, motor tics (eye blinking, head jerking), vocal tics (throat clearing, grunting), tics temporarily suppressible, and tics worsen with stress.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of akathisia?
questions.answer: Akathisia symptoms include inner sense of restlessness, compelling urge to move, pacing, rocking, shifting weight, inability to sit still, anxiety, and symptoms often medication-induced.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of bradykinesia?
questions.answer: Bradykinesia symptoms include slowness of movement, difficulty initiating movements, reduced arm swing when walking, smaller handwriting, soft or monotone speech, and masked facial expression.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of akinesia?
questions.answer: Akinesia symptoms include complete or near-complete loss of movement, difficulty initiating movement, poverty of movement, reduced spontaneous movements, and freezing episodes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of rigidity?
questions.answer: Rigidity symptoms include stiffness in muscles, resistance to passive movement, cogwheel rigidity (jerky resistance), lead-pipe rigidity (constant resistance), reduced range of motion, and pain or aching in muscles.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of postural instability?
questions.answer: Postural instability symptoms include difficulty maintaining balance, tendency to fall backward, difficulty adjusting to pushes or pulls, shuffling gait, difficulty turning, and fear of falling.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of freezing of gait?
questions.answer: Freezing of gait symptoms include temporary inability to move feet forward, feeling feet stuck to floor, happens when starting to walk or turning, anxiety about walking, and shuffling or festinating when able to move.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of festinating gait?
questions.answer: Festinating gait symptoms include walking with short quick shuffling steps, bent-forward posture, increasing speed as walk continues, difficulty stopping, and risk of falling forward.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ataxic gait?
questions.answer: Ataxic gait symptoms include wide-based stance, unsteady walking, staggering, difficulty with heel-to-toe walking, difficulty with turns, increased risk of falls, and compensatory movements.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of steppage gait?
questions.answer: Steppage gait symptoms include high stepping, foot drop, slapping of foot on ground, difficulty lifting front of foot, need to lift knee high, and increased risk of tripping.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of waddling gait?
questions.answer: Waddling gait symptoms include swaying from side to side, difficulty climbing stairs, exaggerated hip movements, weak hip muscles, duck-like walking pattern, and difficulty rising from sitting.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hemiplegic gait?
questions.answer: Hemiplegic gait symptoms include circumduction of leg (swinging leg in arc), stiffness on one side, dragging of affected leg, arm held close to body on affected side, and asymmetric walking pattern.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of scissoring gait?
questions.answer: Scissoring gait symptoms include legs crossing over each other, stiff movements, toe walking, knees and thighs hitting or crossing, difficulty separating legs, and associated with spasticity.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of antalgic gait?
questions.answer: Antalgic gait symptoms include limping to avoid pain, shortened stance phase on painful side, reduced weight-bearing on affected leg, protective posturing, and pain with walking.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sensory ataxia?
questions.answer: Sensory ataxia symptoms include unsteady gait especially in dark, heavy stomping, watching feet while walking, difficulty with balance when eyes closed, loss of position sense, and wide-based stance.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of vestibular ataxia?
questions.answer: Vestibular ataxia symptoms include unsteady gait, dizziness, vertigo, tendency to fall to one side, difficulty with head movements, nausea, and imbalance especially with turns.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of apraxic gait?
questions.answer: Apraxic gait symptoms include difficulty initiating walking, magnetic gait (feet seem stuck), short shuffling steps, preserved ability to perform leg movements when lying down, and normal strength and coordination.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of psychogenic gait disorder?
questions.answer: Psychogenic gait disorder symptoms include inconsistent gait pattern, bizarre or dramatic movements, excessive slowness or hesitation, preserved balance in challenging situations, improvement with distraction, and no organic cause found.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurogenic bladder?
questions.answer: Neurogenic bladder symptoms include inability to control urination, urinary retention, frequent urination, urgent need to urinate, inability to empty bladder completely, urinary incontinence, and recurrent urinary tract infections.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurogenic bowel?
questions.answer: Neurogenic bowel symptoms include constipation, fecal incontinence, inability to control bowel movements, difficulty with evacuation, abdominal distension, irregular bowel movements, and hemorrhoids.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia?
questions.answer: Autonomic dysreflexia symptoms include sudden severe high blood pressure, pounding headache, flushing above injury level, pale skin below injury level, profuse sweating, slow heart rate, blurred vision, and anxiety.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of orthostatic hypotension?
questions.answer: Orthostatic hypotension symptoms include dizziness or lightheadedness when standing, blurred vision, weakness, fatigue, nausea, confusion, fainting, and symptoms improve when sitting or lying down.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome?
questions.answer: Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome symptoms include rapid heartbeat upon standing, dizziness, lightheadedness, fatigue, exercise intolerance, nausea, difficulty concentrating, headache, and fainting.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurocardiogenic syncope?
questions.answer: Neurocardiogenic syncope symptoms include sudden fainting, lightheadedness, nausea, sweating, blurred vision, pale skin, slow heart rate before fainting, and quick recovery after lying down.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Horner's syndrome?
questions.answer: Horner's syndrome symptoms include drooping eyelid on one side, small pupil on one side, decreased sweating on one side of face, redness of affected eye, and symptoms on same side of face.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Adie's pupil?
questions.answer: Adie's pupil symptoms include one pupil larger than the other, slow or absent response to light, better response to near vision, absent or reduced reflexes in limbs, and symptoms usually affect one eye.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Argyll Robertson pupil?
questions.answer: Argyll Robertson pupil symptoms include small irregular pupils, pupils don't respond to light, pupils constrict with near vision (accommodation reflex preserved), bilateral involvement, and associated with neurosyphilis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Marcus Gunn pupil?
questions.answer: Marcus Gunn pupil symptoms include relative afferent pupillary defect, pupil dilates instead of constricts when light swung to it, swinging flashlight test positive, and indicates optic nerve dysfunction.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of optic neuritis?
questions.answer: Optic neuritis symptoms include sudden vision loss (usually one eye), pain with eye movement, color vision changes, visual field defects, flashing lights, and most people recover vision over weeks to months.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of papilledema?
questions.answer: Papilledema symptoms include blurred vision, brief vision blackouts, headache, nausea and vomiting, vision loss (if prolonged), double vision, and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of optic atrophy?
questions.answer: Optic atrophy symptoms include gradual vision loss, loss of color vision, decreased visual acuity, visual field defects, pale optic disc on examination, and irreversible vision impairment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hemianopia?
questions.answer: Hemianopia symptoms include loss of half of visual field, difficulty reading, bumping into objects on affected side, difficulty with depth perception, and may not be aware of visual loss initially.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of quadrantanopia?
questions.answer: Quadrantanopia symptoms include loss of quarter of visual field, missing objects in affected quadrant, difficulty with navigation, reading difficulties, and indicates specific location of brain lesion.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cortical blindness?
questions.answer: Cortical blindness symptoms include complete or partial vision loss, normal pupillary responses, intact eye structures, possible denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), and bilateral occipital lobe damage.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of visual neglect?
questions.answer: Visual neglect symptoms include ignoring objects on one side, not eating food on one side of plate, difficulty dressing one side of body, unaware of neglect, and associated with right brain damage.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of prosopagnosia?
questions.answer: Prosopagnosia symptoms include inability to recognize faces (even familiar ones), relying on other cues (voice, clothing), difficulty following movies with many characters, social anxiety, and preserved ability to recognize objects.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of achromatopsia?
questions.answer: Achromatopsia symptoms include complete color blindness (seeing in shades of gray), sensitivity to bright light, reduced visual acuity, nystagmus, and symptoms present from birth.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Charles Bonnet syndrome?
questions.answer: Charles Bonnet syndrome symptoms include visual hallucinations with vision loss, seeing patterns or complex scenes, knowing hallucinations aren't real, no other mental illness, and more common in elderly.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of nystagmus?
questions.answer: Nystagmus symptoms include involuntary eye movements (rhythmic shaking), reduced vision, head tilting or turning to see better, balance problems, dizziness, and difficulty focusing on objects.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.answer: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia symptoms include impaired eye movement toward nose, nystagmus in opposite eye, diplopia (double vision) when looking to side, and often associated with multiple sclerosis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of progressive external ophthalmoplegia?
questions.answer: Progressive external ophthalmoplegia symptoms include gradual weakness of eye muscles, drooping eyelids (ptosis), difficulty moving eyes in all directions, double vision, and often mitochondrial disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of oculomotor nerve palsy?
questions.answer: Oculomotor nerve palsy symptoms include drooping eyelid, eye turned down and out, double vision, dilated pupil, inability to move eye up, down or in, and headache if caused by aneurysm.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of trochlear nerve palsy?
questions.answer: Trochlear nerve palsy symptoms include double vision (especially looking down), difficulty reading, difficulty with stairs, head tilted to opposite side to compensate, and eye higher than other eye.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of abducens nerve palsy?
questions.answer: Abducens nerve palsy symptoms include inability to move eye outward, eye turns inward, double vision when looking to affected side, need to turn head to see, and often caused by increased pressure.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of vestibular neuritis?
questions.answer: Vestibular neuritis symptoms include sudden severe vertigo, nausea and vomiting, balance problems, difficulty walking, nystagmus, no hearing loss, and symptoms improve over days to weeks.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of labyrinthitis?
questions.answer: Labyrinthitis symptoms include vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus (ringing in ear), nausea and vomiting, balance problems, ear fullness, and symptoms caused by inner ear infection or inflammation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Meniere's disease?
questions.answer: Meniere's disease symptoms include episodic vertigo (lasting 20 minutes to hours), fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, ear fullness or pressure, nausea and vomiting, and progressive hearing loss over time.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo?
questions.answer: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo symptoms include brief episodes of vertigo with head position changes, spinning sensation, nausea, loss of balance, abnormal eye movements, and symptoms triggered by specific movements.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of superior canal dehiscence syndrome?
questions.answer: Superior canal dehiscence syndrome symptoms include vertigo with loud noises or pressure changes, autophony (hearing own voice loudly), hearing eye movements, pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and balance problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of perilymphatic fistula?
questions.answer: Perilymphatic fistula symptoms include vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, ear fullness, imbalance, nausea, sensitivity to pressure changes, and symptoms worsen with straining or loud noises.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of acoustic trauma?
questions.answer: Acoustic trauma symptoms include sudden hearing loss, tinnitus, ear pain, ear fullness, sensitivity to sounds, vertigo, and symptoms after exposure to loud noise or blast.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sensorineural hearing loss?
questions.answer: Sensorineural hearing loss symptoms include difficulty hearing high-pitched sounds, muffled hearing, difficulty understanding speech (especially in noise), tinnitus, and gradual or sudden onset.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of conductive hearing loss?
questions.answer: Conductive hearing loss symptoms include decreased hearing, sounds seem muffled, own voice sounds louder, pain or drainage from ear, ear fullness, and improvement with hearing aids.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of auditory processing disorder?
questions.answer: Auditory processing disorder symptoms include difficulty understanding speech in noise, asking for repetition frequently, difficulty following directions, poor listening skills, academic difficulties, and normal hearing test.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hyperacusis?
questions.answer: Hyperacusis symptoms include oversensitivity to sounds, pain or discomfort with normal sounds, need to cover ears, social withdrawal, anxiety about sounds, and tinnitus often present.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of misophonia?
questions.answer: Misophonia symptoms include strong emotional reaction to specific sounds, anger or panic response, avoidance of triggering situations, anxiety, often triggered by chewing or breathing sounds.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of tinnitus?
questions.answer: Tinnitus symptoms include ringing in ears, buzzing, hissing, or other sounds, sounds worse in quiet environments, difficulty concentrating, sleep problems, anxiety or depression, and no external sound source.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of pulsatile tinnitus?
questions.answer: Pulsatile tinnitus symptoms include rhythmic sound in sync with heartbeat, whooshing or thumping sound, sound in one or both ears, symptoms may worsen with exercise or position changes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anosmia?
questions.answer: Anosmia symptoms include complete loss of smell, inability to detect odors, reduced sense of taste, difficulty enjoying food, inability to detect danger (smoke, gas), and potential depression.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hyposmia?
questions.answer: Hyposmia symptoms include reduced ability to smell, decreased enjoyment of food, difficulty identifying odors, reduced sense of taste, and may not notice spoiled food or gas leaks.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of parosmia?
questions.answer: Parosmia symptoms include distorted sense of smell, unpleasant odors from normal smells, difficulty enjoying food, nausea with certain smells, and often occurs after viral infection or head injury.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of phantosmia?
questions.answer: Phantosmia symptoms include smelling odors that aren't present, often unpleasant smells (burnt, metallic), smells may come and go, one or both nostrils affected, and can be sign of various conditions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ageusia?
questions.answer: Ageusia symptoms include complete loss of taste, inability to detect sweet, sour, salty, bitter, or umami, reduced appetite, weight loss, depression, and often accompanied by smell loss.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hypogeusia?
questions.answer: Hypogeusia symptoms include reduced ability to taste, diminished enjoyment of food, difficulty identifying tastes, possible weight loss or gain, and may be temporary or permanent.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dysgeusia?
questions.answer: Dysgeusia symptoms include distorted taste perception, metallic or bitter taste, unpleasant taste from normal foods, reduced appetite, weight loss, and often accompanies smell disorders.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of burning mouth syndrome?
questions.answer: Burning mouth syndrome symptoms include burning sensation in mouth, tongue, or lips, dry mouth, altered taste (metallic or bitter), increased thirst, and symptoms often worse later in day.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of glossopharyngeal neuralgia?
questions.answer: Glossopharyngeal neuralgia symptoms include severe pain in back of throat, tongue, or ear, pain triggered by swallowing, speaking or coughing, brief episodes of intense pain, and sometimes fainting or slow heart rate.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hypoglossal nerve palsy?
questions.answer: Hypoglossal nerve palsy symptoms include tongue weakness, tongue deviation to affected side, difficulty moving tongue, slurred speech, difficulty chewing and swallowing, and tongue atrophy over time.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of bulbar palsy?
questions.answer: Bulbar palsy symptoms include difficulty swallowing, difficulty speaking (dysarthria), drooling, tongue weakness and atrophy, nasal speech, choking, and affects lower motor neurons.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of pseudobulbar palsy?
questions.answer: Pseudobulbar palsy symptoms include difficulty swallowing, slurred speech, emotional lability (inappropriate laughing or crying), exaggerated reflexes, tongue spasticity, and affects upper motor neurons.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dysarthria?
questions.answer: Dysarthria symptoms include slurred speech, slow speech, rapid speech, mumbling, hoarse or breathy voice, monotone speech, difficulty controlling volume, and drooling.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of apraxia of speech?
questions.answer: Apraxia of speech symptoms include difficulty sequencing sounds, inconsistent speech errors, groping movements of mouth, difficulty starting speech, stress placed on wrong syllables, and aware of errors.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Broca's aphasia?
questions.answer: Broca's aphasia symptoms include difficulty producing speech, telegraphic speech (short phrases), good comprehension, frustration with speech difficulties, preserved ability to read, and writing difficulties similar to speech.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Wernicke's aphasia?
questions.answer: Wernicke's aphasia symptoms include fluent but nonsensical speech, poor comprehension, made-up words (neologisms), unaware of speech errors, difficulty naming objects, and reading and writing impairment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of global aphasia?
questions.answer: Global aphasia symptoms include severe impairment in speech production, severe impairment in comprehension, limited vocabulary, difficulty reading and writing, may use gestures, and most severe form of aphasia.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anomic aphasia?
questions.answer: Anomic aphasia symptoms include difficulty finding words (especially nouns), using general terms instead of specific words, circumlocution (talking around word), preserved grammar and comprehension, and frustration.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of conduction aphasia?
questions.answer: Conduction aphasia symptoms include difficulty repeating words, frequent pauses searching for words, awareness of errors, good comprehension, relatively fluent speech, and intact reading comprehension.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of transcortical motor aphasia?
questions.answer: Transcortical motor aphasia symptoms include difficulty initiating speech, good ability to repeat, good comprehension, short responses, preserved automatic speech, and similar to Broca's but with preserved repetition.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of transcortical sensory aphasia?
questions.answer: Transcortical sensory aphasia symptoms include fluent speech, poor comprehension, good ability to repeat, echolalia (repeating others), difficulty naming objects, and similar to Wernicke's but with preserved repetition.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of mixed transcortical aphasia?
questions.answer: Mixed transcortical aphasia symptoms include preserved ability to repeat, severely impaired spontaneous speech, severely impaired comprehension, echolalia, and preservation of automatic phrases.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of alexia?
questions.answer: Alexia symptoms include inability to read, preserved ability to write in some cases, letter recognition difficulty, may read letter by letter, normal vision, and understanding of spoken language preserved.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of agraphia?
questions.answer: Agraphia symptoms include inability to write, spelling errors, letter formation difficulties, poor grammar in writing, preserved ability to read in some cases, and difficulty copying written text.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of acalculia?
questions.answer: Acalculia symptoms include difficulty performing calculations, difficulty understanding numbers, trouble with math concepts, difficulty telling time, problems with money management, and spatial difficulties with numbers.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Gerstmann syndrome?
questions.answer: Gerstmann syndrome symptoms include difficulty writing (agraphia), difficulty with calculations (acalculia), unable to identify own fingers, difficulty distinguishing left from right, and lesion in dominant parietal lobe.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of alien hand syndrome?
questions.answer: Alien hand syndrome symptoms include involuntary hand movements, hand performs purposeful actions, feeling hand doesn't belong to self, conflict between two hands, difficulty controlling affected hand.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ideomotor apraxia?
questions.answer: Ideomotor apraxia symptoms include inability to perform learned movements on command, can perform spontaneously, difficulty miming tool use, makes errors in sequencing, and preserved automatic movements.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ideational apraxia?
questions.answer: Ideational apraxia symptoms include inability to carry out complex sequences, can do individual steps, difficulty using objects properly, confusion about order of steps, and loss of conceptual knowledge.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of constructional apraxia?
questions.answer: Constructional apraxia symptoms include difficulty drawing or copying figures, inability to assemble objects, difficulty with spatial relationships, problems with puzzles, and difficulty with dressing.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dressing apraxia?
questions.answer: Dressing apraxia symptoms include difficulty putting on clothes, confusion about which limb goes where, inability to orient clothing properly, frustration with dressing, and often associated with right brain damage.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of oculomotor apraxia?
questions.answer: Oculomotor apraxia symptoms include difficulty shifting gaze voluntarily, head thrusting to change fixation, normal eye movements when following moving objects, difficulty with reading, and present from infancy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of limb-kinetic apraxia?
