questions.answer: Growth hormone deficiency symptoms in children include short stature, slow growth rate, delayed puberty. In adults: decreased muscle mass, increased body fat, fatigue, decreased bone density, and mood changes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of prolactinoma?
questions.answer: Prolactinoma symptoms include irregular or absent periods, breast milk production (not related to childbirth), erectile dysfunction, decreased sex drive, infertility, and tumor producing excess prolactin.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of empty nest syndrome?
questions.answer: Empty nest syndrome symptoms include sadness, loss of purpose, worry about children, difficulty adjusting, loneliness, identity crisis, and not a clinical diagnosis but adjustment period when children leave home.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of burnout?
questions.answer: Burnout symptoms include emotional exhaustion, cynicism, reduced professional efficacy, physical fatigue, insomnia, difficulty concentrating, irritability, and state of chronic workplace stress.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of compassion fatigue?
questions.answer: Compassion fatigue symptoms include emotional exhaustion, reduced empathy, difficulty separating work from personal life, physical fatigue, difficulty sleeping, irritability, and affects caregivers and healthcare workers.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of adjustment disorder?
questions.answer: Adjustment disorder symptoms include sadness, anxiety, worry, difficulty concentrating, feeling overwhelmed, withdrawal from social activities, develops within 3 months of stressor, and symptoms resolve within 6 months.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of acute stress disorder?
questions.answer: Acute stress disorder symptoms include intrusive memories, nightmares, dissociation, avoidance, negative mood, anxiety, occurs within one month of traumatic event, and lasts 3 days to 4 weeks.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of complex PTSD?
questions.answer: Complex PTSD symptoms include all PTSD symptoms plus difficulty controlling emotions, negative self-perception, relationship difficulties, feeling detached, loss of sense of meaning, and results from prolonged trauma.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of reactive attachment disorder in adults?
questions.answer: Reactive attachment disorder in adults symptoms include difficulty trusting others, difficulty forming close relationships, fear of abandonment, difficulty regulating emotions, and results from childhood neglect or abuse.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of disinhibited social engagement disorder in adults?
questions.answer: Disinhibited social engagement disorder in adults symptoms include overly familiar behavior with strangers, poor boundaries, indiscriminate trust, impulsive relationships, and results from childhood neglect or institutional care.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of internet gaming disorder?
questions.answer: Internet gaming disorder symptoms include preoccupation with gaming, withdrawal symptoms when not gaming, tolerance (need to spend more time), inability to reduce gaming, loss of other interests, and continued gaming despite problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of gambling disorder?
questions.answer: Gambling disorder symptoms include preoccupation with gambling, need to gamble with increasing amounts, inability to control gambling, restlessness when trying to stop, gambling to escape problems, and lying about gambling.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sex addiction?
questions.answer: Sex addiction symptoms include preoccupation with sexual thoughts, compulsive sexual behavior, inability to control behavior, continued behavior despite negative consequences, withdrawal symptoms, and relationship problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of shopping addiction?
questions.answer: Shopping addiction symptoms include preoccupation with shopping, shopping when feeling emotional distress, guilt after shopping, financial problems, hiding purchases, inability to stop despite problems, and relationship issues.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of food addiction?
questions.answer: Food addiction symptoms include eating more than planned, inability to stop eating despite fullness, going out of way to obtain certain foods, continued eating despite health problems, and withdrawal symptoms when stopping.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of orthorexia?
questions.answer: Orthorexia symptoms include obsession with healthy eating, rigid dietary rules, anxiety about food quality, avoidance of social events involving food, malnutrition despite focus on health, and not officially recognized diagnosis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of exercise addiction?
questions.answer: Exercise addiction symptoms include compulsion to exercise, withdrawal symptoms when unable to exercise, tolerance (need to exercise more), exercise despite injury or illness, and interference with relationships and responsibilities.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of workaholism?
questions.answer: Workaholism symptoms include compulsion to work excessively, inability to stop working, neglect of relationships and health, anxiety when not working, defining self-worth by work, and difficulty relaxing.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of smartphone addiction?
questions.answer: Smartphone addiction symptoms include excessive smartphone use, anxiety when phone not available, neglect of responsibilities, sleep problems, neck and eye strain, and interference with relationships and activities.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of social media addiction?
questions.answer: Social media addiction symptoms include compulsive checking of social media, anxiety about missing out, neglect of real-life relationships, sleep problems, decreased productivity, and mood dependent on social media validation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of caffeine intoxication?
questions.answer: Caffeine intoxication symptoms include restlessness, nervousness, excitement, insomnia, flushed face, increased urination, gastrointestinal disturbance, muscle twitching, rapid heartbeat, and rambling speech.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of caffeine withdrawal?
questions.answer: Caffeine withdrawal symptoms include headache, fatigue, drowsiness, difficulty concentrating, irritability, depression, nausea, muscle pain, and develops 12-24 hours after stopping caffeine.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of nicotine withdrawal?
questions.answer: Nicotine withdrawal symptoms include irritability, anxiety, difficulty concentrating, increased appetite, restlessness, depressed mood, insomnia, craving for nicotine, and symptoms peak within first few days.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of vaping-related illness?
questions.answer: Vaping-related illness symptoms include cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fever, fatigue, weight loss, and can cause severe lung injury (EVALI).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of inhalant intoxication?
questions.answer: Inhalant intoxication symptoms include dizziness, slurred speech, lack of coordination, euphoria, hallucinations, delusions, nausea, nosebleeds, and can cause sudden death (sudden sniffing death syndrome).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of synthetic cannabinoid intoxication?
questions.answer: Synthetic cannabinoid intoxication symptoms include rapid heart rate, vomiting, agitation, confusion, hallucinations, seizures, kidney damage, and more dangerous than natural cannabis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of bath salts intoxication?
questions.answer: Bath salts intoxication symptoms include agitation, paranoia, hallucinations, chest pain, increased heart rate, high blood pressure, violent behavior, psychosis, and synthetic cathinones.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ketamine intoxication?
questions.answer: Ketamine intoxication symptoms include dissociation, hallucinations, confusion, amnesia, increased heart rate and blood pressure, nausea, numbness, and impaired motor function.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of PCP intoxication?
questions.answer: PCP intoxication symptoms include numbness, hallucinations, delusions, paranoia, agitation, violent behavior, increased strength, nystagmus, elevated heart rate and blood pressure, and impaired judgment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of LSD intoxication?
questions.answer: LSD intoxication symptoms include visual hallucinations, altered perceptions, synesthesia, dilated pupils, increased heart rate, sweating, dizziness, and lasting 8-12 hours.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of psilocybin intoxication?
questions.answer: Psilocybin intoxication symptoms include visual hallucinations, altered perception of time, euphoria, anxiety, nausea, dilated pupils, increased heart rate, and effects last 4-6 hours.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of MDMA intoxication?
questions.answer: MDMA intoxication symptoms include euphoria, increased empathy, enhanced sensory perception, increased heart rate and blood pressure, hyperthermia, teeth grinding, nausea, and dehydration.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of GHB intoxication?
questions.answer: GHB intoxication symptoms include euphoria, drowsiness, dizziness, nausea, confusion, amnesia, respiratory depression, coma, and dangerous when combined with alcohol.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of rohypnol intoxication?
questions.answer: Rohypnol intoxication symptoms include sedation, muscle relaxation, decreased anxiety, amnesia, confusion, impaired judgment, slurred speech, and date rape drug causing memory loss.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of fentanyl overdose?
questions.answer: Fentanyl overdose symptoms include severe respiratory depression, unconsciousness, pinpoint pupils, cold clammy skin, blue lips and fingernails, slow heartbeat, and potentially fatal requiring naloxone.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of methamphetamine intoxication?
questions.answer: Methamphetamine intoxication symptoms include euphoria, increased energy, decreased appetite, rapid heart rate, high blood pressure, hyperthermia, paranoia, hallucinations, and aggressive behavior.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cocaine intoxication?
questions.answer: Cocaine intoxication symptoms include euphoria, increased energy, talkativeness, dilated pupils, rapid heart rate, high blood pressure, hyperthermia, chest pain, and risk of heart attack or stroke.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of crack cocaine intoxication?
questions.answer: Crack cocaine intoxication symptoms include intense but brief euphoria, increased alertness, paranoia, anxiety, rapid heart rate, high blood pressure, risk of stroke, and more addictive than powder cocaine.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of heroin intoxication?
questions.answer: Heroin intoxication symptoms include euphoria, warm flushing, dry mouth, heavy feeling in limbs, clouded thinking, drowsiness, respiratory depression, and potentially fatal overdose.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of prescription opioid abuse?
questions.answer: Prescription opioid abuse symptoms include drowsiness, confusion, constipation, nausea, slowed breathing, euphoria when taking more than prescribed, and risk of addiction and overdose.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of benzodiazepine abuse?
questions.answer: Benzodiazepine abuse symptoms include drowsiness, confusion, slurred speech, impaired coordination, memory problems, respiratory depression when combined with other depressants, and risk of dependence.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of prescription stimulant abuse?
questions.answer: Prescription stimulant abuse symptoms include increased alertness, euphoria, decreased appetite, insomnia, rapid heart rate, high blood pressure, paranoia, and risk of cardiovascular problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anabolic steroid abuse?
questions.answer: Anabolic steroid abuse symptoms include increased muscle mass, acne, mood swings, aggression (roid rage), liver damage, cardiovascular problems, shrinking testicles in men, masculinization in women.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of performance-enhancing drug abuse?
questions.answer: Performance-enhancing drug abuse symptoms vary by substance but may include cardiovascular problems, hormonal imbalances, liver damage, mood changes, aggression, and dependency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of polydrug use?
questions.answer: Polydrug use symptoms vary depending on substances but include increased risk of overdose, unpredictable effects, organ damage, cognitive impairment, and using multiple substances simultaneously or sequentially.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of substance use disorder?
questions.answer: Substance use disorder symptoms include inability to control use, continued use despite problems, tolerance, withdrawal, giving up activities, spending significant time obtaining or using substance, and cravings.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of addiction relapse?
questions.answer: Addiction relapse symptoms include return to substance use after period of abstinence, romanticizing past use, isolating from support, stopping recovery activities, and often preceded by emotional and mental relapse.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of post-acute withdrawal syndrome?
questions.answer: Post-acute withdrawal syndrome symptoms include mood swings, anxiety, irritability, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, sleep disturbances, and can last months to years after stopping substance use.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dual diagnosis?
questions.answer: Dual diagnosis symptoms include symptoms of both mental illness and substance use disorder, difficulty managing emotions, impulsive behavior, social isolation, and requires integrated treatment approach.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of treatment-resistant depression?
questions.answer: Treatment-resistant depression symptoms include persistent depression despite trying multiple antidepressants, severe impairment in daily functioning, thoughts of self-harm, and may require alternative treatments like ECT or TMS.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of treatment-resistant schizophrenia?
questions.answer: Treatment-resistant schizophrenia symptoms include persistent hallucinations and delusions despite trying multiple antipsychotics, severe functional impairment, frequent hospitalizations, and may require clozapine treatment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of treatment-resistant bipolar disorder?
questions.answer: Treatment-resistant bipolar disorder symptoms include frequent mood episodes despite medication, severe functional impairment, rapid cycling, mixed episodes, and may require combination therapy or ECT.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of treatment-resistant anxiety?
questions.answer: Treatment-resistant anxiety symptoms include persistent severe anxiety despite trying multiple medications and therapy, panic attacks, avoidance behaviors, significant impairment in daily life, and may require alternative treatments.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of treatment-resistant OCD?
questions.answer: Treatment-resistant OCD symptoms include severe obsessions and compulsions despite trying multiple SSRIs and therapy, significant time spent on rituals, severe impairment, and may require augmentation strategies or neurosurgery.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of refractory epilepsy?
questions.answer: Refractory epilepsy symptoms include frequent seizures despite trying multiple antiepileptic medications, risk of injury, cognitive impairment, developmental delays in children, and may require surgery or VNS.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of status epilepticus?
questions.answer: Status epilepticus symptoms include continuous seizure lasting more than 5 minutes or multiple seizures without regaining consciousness between, medical emergency, can cause brain damage, and potentially fatal.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of non-convulsive status epilepticus?
questions.answer: Non-convulsive status epilepticus symptoms include altered consciousness, confusion, behavioral changes, subtle facial twitching, staring spells, no major convulsions, and requires EEG for diagnosis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of absence status epilepticus?
questions.answer: Absence status epilepticus symptoms include prolonged altered consciousness, confusion, automatic behaviors, mild facial twitching, no major convulsions, and can last hours to days if untreated.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy?
questions.answer: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy symptoms include myoclonic jerks (especially in morning), generalized tonic-clonic seizures, absence seizures sometimes, triggered by sleep deprivation and stress, onset in adolescence.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome?
questions.answer: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome symptoms include multiple seizure types, intellectual disability, behavioral problems, slow spike-and-wave pattern on EEG, difficult to treat, and childhood-onset epilepsy syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Dravet syndrome?
questions.answer: Dravet syndrome symptoms include prolonged seizures starting in infancy, developmental delays, intellectual disability, movement and balance issues, sleep disturbances, and severe genetic epilepsy syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of West syndrome?
questions.answer: West syndrome symptoms include infantile spasms (clusters of brief seizures), developmental regression, hypsarrhythmia pattern on EEG, occurs in first year of life, and poor developmental outcome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Landau-Kleffner syndrome?
questions.answer: Landau-Kleffner syndrome symptoms include acquired aphasia (loss of language skills), seizures, behavioral problems, continuous spike-wave activity during sleep on EEG, onset in childhood.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Rasmussen syndrome?
questions.answer: Rasmussen syndrome symptoms include frequent seizures, progressive weakness on one side of body, cognitive decline, inflammation of one hemisphere, and may require hemispherectomy surgery.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of febrile seizures?
questions.answer: Febrile seizures symptoms include seizures triggered by fever, occur in young children (6 months to 5 years), brief duration, full recovery, and usually benign with no long-term effects.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of psychogenic non-epileptic seizures?
questions.answer: Psychogenic non-epileptic seizures symptoms include seizure-like episodes, eyes typically closed during episode, gradual onset and offset, no postictal confusion, normal EEG during episode, and psychological cause.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of reflex epilepsy?
questions.answer: Reflex epilepsy symptoms include seizures triggered by specific stimuli (flashing lights, reading, music, eating), photosensitivity common, and seizures can be prevented by avoiding triggers.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of catamenial epilepsy?
questions.answer: Catamenial epilepsy symptoms include seizures that worsen around menstruation, hormone-related seizure patterns, more frequent seizures during certain menstrual cycle phases, and affects women with epilepsy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of gelastic seizures?
questions.answer: Gelastic seizures symptoms include sudden inappropriate laughter, brief duration, no loss of consciousness always, often associated with hypothalamic hamartoma, and can be mistaken for behavioral problem.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of drop attacks?
questions.answer: Drop attacks symptoms include sudden loss of muscle tone causing fall, no loss of consciousness, brief duration, can result in injury, and various causes including seizures, cardiac, or neurological problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of syncope?
questions.answer: Syncope symptoms include brief loss of consciousness, falling, preceded by lightheadedness, nausea, sweating, blurred vision, spontaneous recovery, and caused by temporary decrease in blood flow to brain.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of vasovagal syncope?
questions.answer: Vasovagal syncope symptoms include fainting triggered by specific situations (standing long, seeing blood, pain), preceded by warning signs, pallor, sweating, nausea, and most common type of fainting.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cardiac syncope?
questions.answer: Cardiac syncope symptoms include sudden fainting without warning, occurs during exertion sometimes, palpitations, chest pain, shortness of breath, and indicates serious heart condition requiring evaluation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of situational syncope?
questions.answer: Situational syncope symptoms include fainting during or after specific activities (coughing, swallowing, urination, defecation), brief loss of consciousness, spontaneous recovery, and caused by vagal stimulation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of carotid sinus hypersensitivity?
questions.answer: Carotid sinus hypersensitivity symptoms include dizziness or fainting when pressure applied to carotid sinus (tight collar, turning head, shaving), slow heart rate, drop in blood pressure.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of breath-holding spells?
questions.answer: Breath-holding spells symptoms include child holds breath until losing consciousness, triggered by anger or fear, brief duration, spontaneous recovery, benign condition in young children.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hyperventilation syndrome?
questions.answer: Hyperventilation syndrome symptoms include rapid breathing, lightheadedness, chest tightness, tingling in hands and feet, muscle spasms, anxiety, feeling of suffocation, and caused by breathing too fast.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of breath-holding attacks?
questions.answer: Breath-holding attacks symptoms include voluntary breath holding, cyanosis (blue color), loss of consciousness if prolonged, seizure-like movements sometimes, and behavioral component in children.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of transient global amnesia?
questions.answer: Transient global amnesia symptoms include sudden inability to form new memories, confusion about recent events, repetitive questioning, preserved personal identity, lasts hours then resolves completely, and benign condition.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of amnesia?
questions.answer: Amnesia symptoms include inability to recall past events (retrograde amnesia), inability to form new memories (anterograde amnesia), confusion, disorientation, and various causes including injury, disease, psychological trauma.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of retrograde amnesia?
questions.answer: Retrograde amnesia symptoms include inability to recall events before injury or illness, memory loss extends backward in time, recent memories more affected than remote memories, and preserved ability to form new memories.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anterograde amnesia?
questions.answer: Anterograde amnesia symptoms include inability to form new memories after injury or illness, preserved old memories, difficulty learning new information, repetition of questions, and severe functional impairment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of post-traumatic amnesia?
questions.answer: Post-traumatic amnesia symptoms include confusion and disorientation after head injury, inability to form new memories, agitation, memory gap for period after injury, and duration indicates severity of injury.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of childhood amnesia?
questions.answer: Childhood amnesia symptoms include inability to recall events from early childhood (before age 3-4), normal phenomenon in all people, and related to brain development and language acquisition.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of source amnesia?
questions.answer: Source amnesia symptoms include remembering information but not remembering where or how learned, confusion about origin of memories, and common in normal aging and certain brain conditions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of semantic dementia?
questions.answer: Semantic dementia symptoms include loss of word meaning, difficulty naming objects, surface dyslexia, preserved episodic memory initially, behavioral changes, and progressive loss of semantic knowledge.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of mild cognitive impairment?
questions.answer: Mild cognitive impairment symptoms include noticeable memory or thinking problems, but able to perform daily activities independently, forgetfulness, difficulty concentrating, and increased risk of developing dementia.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of age-related cognitive decline?
questions.answer: Age-related cognitive decline symptoms include mild slowing of processing speed, occasional forgetfulness, difficulty with multitasking, tip-of-tongue phenomenon, and normal part of aging not dementia.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cognitive impairment post-COVID?
questions.answer: Cognitive impairment post-COVID symptoms include brain fog, difficulty concentrating, memory problems, mental fatigue, confusion, difficulty with word-finding, and part of long COVID syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of long COVID?
questions.answer: Long COVID symptoms include fatigue, shortness of breath, cognitive impairment (brain fog), headache, dizziness, joint pain, chest pain, heart palpitations, and symptoms persisting weeks to months after acute infection.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of post-viral fatigue syndrome?
questions.answer: Post-viral fatigue syndrome symptoms include persistent fatigue not relieved by rest, muscle pain, headaches, sleep problems, difficulty concentrating, sore throat, and follows viral infection.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of myalgic encephalomyelitis?
questions.answer: Myalgic encephalomyelitis symptoms include severe fatigue, post-exertional malaise (worsening after activity), unrefreshing sleep, cognitive impairment, orthostatic intolerance, and also called chronic fatigue syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of mast cell activation syndrome?
questions.answer: Mast cell activation syndrome symptoms include flushing, itching, hives, abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, rapid heart rate, low blood pressure, brain fog, and episodes triggered by various factors.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome?
questions.answer: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome symptoms include joint hypermobility, frequent dislocations, skin hyperelasticity, easy bruising, chronic pain, fatigue, and connective tissue disorder with multiple types.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Marfan syndrome?
questions.answer: Marfan syndrome symptoms include tall stature, long limbs, flexible joints, heart problems (aortic aneurysm), lens dislocation, scoliosis, and connective tissue disorder affecting multiple systems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism?
questions.answer: Neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism symptoms include tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, shuffling gait, masked face, caused by antipsychotic medications, and usually reversible when medication stopped.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of drug-induced dystonia?
questions.answer: Drug-induced dystonia symptoms include involuntary muscle contractions, abnormal postures, tongue protrusion, neck twisting, eye deviation, caused by antipsychotics or antiemetics, and treated with anticholinergics.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia?
questions.answer: Neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia symptoms include sudden muscle spasms, neck twisting (torticollis), tongue protrusion, eye deviation upward (oculogyric crisis), occurs within days of starting antipsychotic.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neuroleptic-induced akathisia?
questions.answer: Neuroleptic-induced akathisia symptoms include inner restlessness, inability to sit still, pacing, rocking, anxiety, agitation, distress, caused by antipsychotics, and can be mistaken for worsening psychiatric symptoms.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neuroleptic-induced tardive dyskinesia?
questions.answer: Neuroleptic-induced tardive dyskinesia symptoms include involuntary facial movements (lip smacking, tongue protrusion, grimacing), rapid eye blinking, limb movements, develops after long-term antipsychotic use.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of medication overuse headache?
questions.answer: Medication overuse headache symptoms include daily or near-daily headaches, worse in morning, relieved temporarily by medication, develops from frequent use of headache medication, and improves with medication withdrawal.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of rebound headache?
questions.answer: Rebound headache symptoms include headache returning as medication wears off, increasing medication use, escalating pain, occurs with frequent use of pain relievers, and same as medication overuse headache.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ice pick headache?
questions.answer: Ice pick headache symptoms include sudden stabbing pain lasting seconds, occurs in head location, can happen multiple times per day, no other symptoms, and also called primary stabbing headache.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of thunderclap headache?
questions.answer: Thunderclap headache symptoms include sudden severe headache reaching maximum intensity within seconds, worst headache of life, may indicate serious condition (aneurysm, stroke), and requires immediate medical evaluation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hypnic headache?
questions.answer: Hypnic headache symptoms include headache that wakes person from sleep, occurs at same time nightly, bilateral pain, occurs in older adults, and sometimes called alarm clock headache.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of new daily persistent headache?
questions.answer: New daily persistent headache symptoms include sudden onset of daily headache, person can remember exact day started, continuous pain, resembles chronic tension headache or migraine, and difficult to treat.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hemiplegic migraine?
questions.answer: Hemiplegic migraine symptoms include temporary weakness on one side of body, vision problems, numbness, difficulty speaking, confusion, and rare form of migraine mimicking stroke.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of retinal migraine?
questions.answer: Retinal migraine symptoms include temporary vision loss or blindness in one eye, lasting minutes to hour, followed by headache, and rare type of migraine affecting one eye.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of vestibular migraine?
questions.answer: Vestibular migraine symptoms include vertigo or dizziness, balance problems, motion sensitivity, nausea, headache may or may not be present, and migraine affecting balance system.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of basilar migraine?
questions.answer: Basilar migraine symptoms include dizziness, double vision, slurred speech, ringing in ears, loss of balance, confusion, temporary blindness, and affects brainstem, now called migraine with brainstem aura.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of abdominal migraine?
questions.answer: Abdominal migraine symptoms include episodes of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, occurs in children, headache may be absent, and considered precursor to typical migraine.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of chronic migraine?
questions.answer: Chronic migraine symptoms include headache 15 or more days per month for at least 3 months, at least 8 days with migraine features, significant disability, and may develop from episodic migraine.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of status migrainosus?
questions.answer: Status migrainosus symptoms include debilitating migraine lasting more than 72 hours, severe pain, nausea, vomiting, dehydration, may require hospitalization, and medical emergency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of migrainous infarction?
questions.answer: Migrainous infarction symptoms include migraine aura symptoms lasting more than 60 minutes, neuroimaging shows stroke, one or more aura symptoms associated with ischemic brain lesion, and rare complication.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of persistent aura without infarction?
questions.answer: Persistent aura without infarction symptoms include aura symptoms lasting more than one week, no evidence of stroke on imaging, may include visual symptoms or other aura features.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of migraine-triggered seizure?
questions.answer: Migraine-triggered seizure symptoms include seizure occurring during or within one hour of migraine aura, also called migralepsy, rare phenomenon, and both conditions may share mechanisms.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hemicrania continua?
questions.answer: Hemicrania continua symptoms include continuous one-sided headache, varying intensity, occasional severe attacks with autonomic symptoms, completely responsive to indomethacin, and chronic daily headache.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of paroxysmal hemicrania?
questions.answer: Paroxysmal hemicrania symptoms include frequent short-lasting attacks of severe one-sided headache, autonomic symptoms (tearing, nasal congestion), completely responsive to indomethacin, more common in women.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of SUNCT syndrome?
questions.answer: SUNCT syndrome symptoms include short-lasting attacks (5-240 seconds) of one-sided head pain, prominent tearing and redness of eye, nasal congestion, attacks occur many times daily.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of SUNA syndrome?
questions.answer: SUNA syndrome symptoms include short-lasting attacks of one-sided head pain, autonomic symptoms (may have one autonomic symptom, unlike SUNCT which has both tearing and redness), frequent attacks.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of nummular headache?
questions.answer: Nummular headache symptoms include continuous or intermittent pain in coin-shaped area on scalp, mild to moderate pain, tenderness at site, and rare primary headache disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cold stimulus headache?
questions.answer: Cold stimulus headache symptoms include brief sharp headache triggered by cold food or drink (ice cream headache, brain freeze), pain in forehead or temple, lasts seconds to minutes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of external compression headache?
questions.answer: External compression headache symptoms include pain where external pressure applied to head (tight hat, headband, goggles, helmet), resolves when pressure removed, and also called external pressure headache.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of primary cough headache?
questions.answer: Primary cough headache symptoms include sudden onset headache triggered by coughing, straining, or Valsalva maneuver, bilateral pain, lasts seconds to minutes, and requires exclusion of secondary causes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of primary exercise headache?
questions.answer: Primary exercise headache symptoms include headache during or after strenuous exercise, pulsating quality, lasts minutes to hours, prevented by warming up, and requires exclusion of serious causes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of primary sexual headache?
questions.answer: Primary sexual headache symptoms include headache during sexual activity, sudden or gradual onset, severe at orgasm, lasts minutes to hours, and requires exclusion of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cervicogenic headache?
questions.answer: Cervicogenic headache symptoms include one-sided headache starting in neck, reduced neck range of motion, headache triggered by neck movement, tenderness in neck muscles, and originates from neck structures.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of occipital neuralgia?
questions.answer: Occipital neuralgia symptoms include sharp shooting or electric shock-like pain in back of head, tenderness over occipital nerves, pain triggered by touching scalp, and caused by occipital nerve irritation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of giant cell arteritis?
questions.answer: Giant cell arteritis symptoms include new headache in older adult, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, vision problems, fever, weight loss, and requires immediate treatment to prevent blindness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of intracranial hypotension?
questions.answer: Intracranial hypotension symptoms include severe headache worse when upright, improves lying down, neck pain, nausea, double vision, and caused by CSF leak from lumbar puncture or spontaneous.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of spontaneous intracranial hypotension?
questions.answer: Spontaneous intracranial hypotension symptoms include severe postural headache (worse upright), neck pain, nausea, tinnitus, muffled hearing, caused by spontaneous CSF leak, and may show sagging brain on MRI.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of post-lumbar puncture headache?
questions.answer: Post-lumbar puncture headache symptoms include severe headache worse when upright, improves lying flat, nausea, neck stiffness, develops within days of lumbar puncture, and caused by CSF leak.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of high-altitude headache?
questions.answer: High-altitude headache symptoms include headache developing within 24 hours of ascending above 2500 meters, frontal or bilateral pain, worsens with exertion, and part of acute mountain sickness.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of airplane headache?
questions.answer: Airplane headache symptoms include severe stabbing pain during airplane descent, localized to eye or forehead, brief duration, and thought related to pressure changes in paranasal sinuses.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hangover headache?
questions.answer: Hangover headache symptoms include throbbing headache, nausea, fatigue, sensitivity to light and sound, dehydration, dizziness, develops after alcohol consumption, and caused by alcohol and its metabolites.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of caffeine-withdrawal headache?
questions.answer: Caffeine-withdrawal headache symptoms include throbbing headache, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, nausea, develops 12-24 hours after last caffeine intake, and improves with caffeine.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sinus headache?
questions.answer: Sinus headache symptoms include deep constant pain in forehead, cheekbones, or bridge of nose, pain worsens with head movement, facial pressure, nasal congestion, and associated with sinusitis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dental headache?
questions.answer: Dental headache symptoms include headache with tooth pain, pain worsens with chewing, jaw tenderness, pain refers to head and face, and caused by dental problems like infection or TMJ.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of temporomandibular joint disorder?
questions.answer: Temporomandibular joint disorder symptoms include jaw pain, clicking or popping in jaw, difficulty opening mouth, headache, ear pain, facial pain, and dysfunction of jaw joint and muscles.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of atypical facial pain?
questions.answer: Atypical facial pain symptoms include continuous facial pain, burning or aching quality, poorly localized, no neurological signs, no identifiable cause, and diagnosis of exclusion.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of persistent idiopathic facial pain?
questions.answer: Persistent idiopathic facial pain symptoms include daily continuous pain in face, no clinical or imaging findings, present at least 2 hours per day for 3+ months, and same as atypical facial pain.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of facial myokymia?
questions.answer: Facial myokymia symptoms include continuous fine rippling movements of facial muscles, usually around eye or mouth, visible undulation, not painful, and can be benign or indicate MS or brainstem lesion.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of facial synkinesis?
questions.answer: Facial synkinesis symptoms include involuntary facial movements when making voluntary facial expression, eye closes when smiling, occurs after facial nerve damage or Bell's palsy, and aberrant nerve regeneration.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Ramsay Hunt syndrome?
questions.answer: Ramsay Hunt syndrome symptoms include facial paralysis, painful rash in ear or mouth, hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo, and caused by varicella zoster virus affecting facial nerve.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome?
questions.answer: Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome symptoms include recurrent facial paralysis, facial swelling (especially lips), fissured tongue, and rare neurological disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Moebius syndrome?
questions.answer: Moebius syndrome symptoms include facial paralysis, inability to smile, difficulty with eye movements, feeding problems, limb abnormalities, present from birth, and congenital cranial nerve disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome?
questions.answer: Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome symptoms include eyelid elevates when chewing or moving jaw, present from birth, usually one eye affected, and congenital cranial nerve misdirection.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Duane syndrome?
questions.answer: Duane syndrome symptoms include limited eye movement (usually outward), eye narrowing and retraction when looking certain direction, head turning to compensate, present from birth, and congenital eye movement disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Brown syndrome?
questions.answer: Brown syndrome symptoms include inability to elevate eye when looking toward nose, clicking sensation sometimes, may be congenital or acquired, and superior oblique tendon sheath disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of strabismus?
questions.answer: Strabismus symptoms include misalignment of eyes, eyes not working together, double vision, head tilting to compensate, lazy eye, and may be congenital or acquired, requires evaluation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of amblyopia?
questions.answer: Amblyopia symptoms include reduced vision in one eye, poor depth perception, eye turning in or out, squinting or shutting one eye, and develops in childhood when brain favors one eye (lazy eye).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of diplopia?
questions.answer: Diplopia symptoms include seeing two images of single object, double vision may be horizontal, vertical, or diagonal, closing one eye eliminates double vision, and caused by various conditions affecting eye muscles or nerves.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ptosis?
questions.answer: Ptosis symptoms include drooping of upper eyelid, reduced field of vision, tilting head back to see, eyebrow strain from trying to lift lid, and caused by muscle or nerve problems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of blepharospasm?
questions.answer: Blepharospasm symptoms include involuntary eye closure, increased blinking, eye irritation, light sensitivity, difficulty keeping eyes open, and focal dystonia affecting eyelids.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of lagophthalmos?
questions.answer: Lagophthalmos symptoms include inability to close eyelids completely, dry eyes, eye irritation, corneal damage, tearing, and caused by facial nerve palsy or other conditions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ectropion?
questions.answer: Ectropion symptoms include eyelid turning outward, excessive tearing, dry irritated eyes, sensitivity to light and wind, redness, and usually affects lower eyelid in older adults.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of entropion?
questions.answer: Entropion symptoms include eyelid turning inward, eyelashes rubbing against eye, eye irritation and redness, tearing, sensitivity to light, feeling something in eye, and usually affects lower eyelid.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of photophobia?
questions.answer: Photophobia symptoms include sensitivity to light, discomfort or pain in bright light, squinting, need to wear sunglasses indoors, headache, and associated with various eye and neurological conditions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of visual snow syndrome?
questions.answer: Visual snow syndrome symptoms include continuous tiny dots in entire visual field (like TV static), afterimages, light sensitivity, night blindness, trails following moving objects, and not caused by eye problem.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of palinopsia?
questions.answer: Palinopsia symptoms include seeing afterimages or trails after object moves, images persist after looking away, visual hallucinations, and caused by various brain conditions or medications.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of oscillopsia?
questions.answer: Oscillopsia symptoms include sensation that environment is moving or oscillating, blurred vision with head movement, difficulty reading, balance problems, and caused by vestibular or eye movement disorders.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of metamorphopsia?
questions.answer: Metamorphopsia symptoms include distorted vision, straight lines appear wavy or bent, objects appear different size or shape, and caused by macular problems or other retinal conditions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of micropsia?
questions.answer: Micropsia symptoms include objects appear smaller than actual size, also called Alice in Wonderland syndrome, can affect one or both eyes, and caused by various neurological or eye conditions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of macropsia?
questions.answer: Macropsia symptoms include objects appear larger than actual size, opposite of micropsia, can affect one or both eyes, and caused by various neurological or retinal conditions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Alice in Wonderland syndrome?
questions.answer: Alice in Wonderland syndrome symptoms include distorted perception of size, shape, or time, objects appear larger or smaller, body parts feel wrong size, time seems faster or slower, and often associated with migraine.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of visual agnosia?
questions.answer: Visual agnosia symptoms include inability to recognize objects despite seeing them, can describe features but not identify object, preserved vision, and caused by damage to visual association areas.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of simultanagnosia?
questions.answer: Simultanagnosia symptoms include ability to see only one object at time, cannot perceive visual scene as whole, difficulty reading, missing items in visual field, and part of Balint syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of optic ataxia?
questions.answer: Optic ataxia symptoms include difficulty reaching for objects under visual guidance, hand movements inaccurate, can reach for objects felt but not seen, and part of Balint syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ocular motor apraxia?
questions.answer: Ocular motor apraxia symptoms include difficulty shifting gaze voluntarily, head thrusting to change fixation, preserved ability to follow slowly moving objects, and congenital or acquired.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Parinaud syndrome?
questions.answer: Parinaud syndrome symptoms include inability to look upward, convergence-retraction nystagmus, light-near dissociation (pupils), eyelid retraction, and caused by lesion affecting midbrain.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of one-and-a-half syndrome?
questions.answer: One-and-a-half syndrome symptoms include inability to move affected eye horizontally, inability to move other eye inward when looking toward affected side, preserved outward movement of unaffected eye, and brainstem lesion.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of skew deviation?
questions.answer: Skew deviation symptoms include vertical misalignment of eyes, double vision, head tilt to compensate, and caused by brainstem or cerebellar lesion affecting vestibular pathways.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of convergence insufficiency?
questions.answer: Convergence insufficiency symptoms include difficulty reading, eye strain, headaches, double vision, words moving on page, need to reread lines, and eyes unable to turn inward together.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of convergence spasm?
questions.answer: Convergence spasm symptoms include episodic convergence of eyes, blurred distance vision, headache, associated with looking at near objects, and often functional disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of saccadic intrusions?
questions.answer: Saccadic intrusions symptoms include unwanted rapid eye movements interrupting fixation, square wave jerks, difficulty maintaining gaze, and various causes including cerebellar or brainstem disorders.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of opsoclonus?
questions.answer: Opsoclonus symptoms include rapid chaotic involuntary eye movements in all directions, difficulty focusing, associated with ataxia and myoclonus sometimes, and paraneoplastic syndrome or viral in children.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ocular flutter?
questions.answer: Ocular flutter symptoms include rapid horizontal eye oscillations, brief bursts, occurs when trying to fixate, no intersaccadic interval, and similar to opsoclonus but horizontal only.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of downbeat nystagmus?
questions.answer: Downbeat nystagmus symptoms include eyes drift upward then jerk downward, oscillopsia, blurred vision, imbalance, worse when looking down, and associated with craniocervical junction abnormalities or cerebellar disease.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of upbeat nystagmus?
questions.answer: Upbeat nystagmus symptoms include eyes drift downward then jerk upward, oscillopsia, blurred vision, worse when looking up, and associated with brainstem or cerebellar lesions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of gaze-evoked nystagmus?
questions.answer: Gaze-evoked nystagmus symptoms include nystagmus appears when looking to side, eyes drift toward center, fast phase in direction of gaze, and common with medication effects or cerebellar dysfunction.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of periodic alternating nystagmus?
questions.answer: Periodic alternating nystagmus symptoms include horizontal nystagmus changing direction every few minutes, associated with null point, worse in darkness, and caused by vestibular or cerebellar dysfunction.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of see-saw nystagmus?
questions.answer: See-saw nystagmus symptoms include one eye elevates and intorts while other depresses and extorts, pendular or jerk type, associated with chiasmal lesions, and rare nystagmus pattern.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of congenital nystagmus?
questions.answer: Congenital nystagmus symptoms include eye oscillations present from birth or early infancy, horizontal nystagmus, null point where nystagmus minimal, head turn to null point, and vision often surprisingly good.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of spasmus nutans?
questions.answer: Spasmus nutans symptoms include nystagmus, head nodding, abnormal head position, onset in infancy, usually resolves by age 3-4, and benign condition but requires evaluation to exclude serious causes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of superior oblique myokymia?
questions.answer: Superior oblique myokymia symptoms include monocular torsional oscillations, sensation of image jumping or shaking, episodic, may be visible as flickering, and benign condition affecting one eye.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ocular bobbing?
questions.answer: Ocular bobbing symptoms include rapid downward eye movements followed by slow drift back, absent horizontal eye movements, indicates severe pontine damage, poor prognosis, and seen in comatose patients.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ocular dipping?
questions.answer: Ocular dipping symptoms include slow downward eye movement followed by rapid return, preserved horizontal eye movements, indicates anoxic brain injury or metabolic encephalopathy, and similar to ocular bobbing but different timing.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ping-pong gaze?
questions.answer: Ping-pong gaze symptoms include eyes moving slowly side to side in regular pattern, occurs in comatose patients, indicates bilateral hemisphere dysfunction, and slow horizontal eye deviations.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of doll's eye reflex absence?
questions.answer: Doll's eye reflex absence symptoms include eyes don't move opposite to head rotation, indicates brainstem dysfunction, tested in comatose patients, and abnormal response suggests severe brain injury.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of caloric test abnormality?
questions.answer: Caloric test abnormality symptoms include abnormal or absent eye movement when cold or warm water instilled in ear, indicates vestibular or brainstem dysfunction, and part of coma examination.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of conjugate gaze deviation?
questions.answer: Conjugate gaze deviation symptoms include both eyes deviate to same side, unable to move eyes past midline, gaze preference toward lesion in cortical stroke or away from lesion in brainstem stroke.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of disconjugate gaze?
questions.answer: Disconjugate gaze symptoms include eyes not moving together, misalignment, double vision, indicates brainstem lesion or multiple cranial nerve palsies, and requires urgent evaluation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of gaze palsy?
questions.answer: Gaze palsy symptoms include inability to move both eyes in same direction, preserved individual eye movements, horizontal or vertical gaze palsy, and indicates supranuclear lesion in brain.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of internuclear ophthalmoplegia bilateral?
questions.answer: Bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia symptoms include impaired adduction both eyes, convergence may be affected, nystagmus of abducting eyes, and highly suggestive of multiple sclerosis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of wall-eyed bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.answer: Wall-eyed bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia symptoms include bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia with exotropia (eyes deviate outward), indicates severe bilateral medial longitudinal fasciculus lesion, and rare condition.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of pretectal syndrome?
questions.answer: Pretectal syndrome symptoms include light-near dissociation (pupils react to accommodation but not light), vertical gaze palsy, convergence-retraction nystagmus, and same as Parinaud syndrome affecting dorsal midbrain.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Weber syndrome?
questions.answer: Weber syndrome symptoms include oculomotor nerve palsy on one side (drooping eyelid, dilated pupil, eye turned down and out), weakness on opposite side of body, and ventral midbrain stroke syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Benedikt syndrome?
questions.answer: Benedikt syndrome symptoms include oculomotor nerve palsy on one side, tremor and involuntary movements on opposite side, and tegmental midbrain lesion syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Claude syndrome?
questions.answer: Claude syndrome symptoms include oculomotor nerve palsy on one side, ataxia on opposite side, and midbrain syndrome affecting red nucleus and oculomotor nerve.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Nothnagel syndrome?
questions.answer: Nothnagel syndrome symptoms include oculomotor nerve palsy, cerebellar ataxia, and dorsal midbrain lesion affecting superior cerebellar peduncle and oculomotor nucleus.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of top of the basilar syndrome?
questions.answer: Top of the basilar syndrome symptoms include altered consciousness, visual disturbances, memory problems, hallucinations, abnormal movements, ocular motor abnormalities, and bilateral thalamic and midbrain infarction.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of locked-in syndrome complete?
questions.answer: Complete locked-in syndrome symptoms include total paralysis including eye movements, retained consciousness, can only blink or move eyes vertically sometimes, and most severe form requiring communication technology.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of pontine hemorrhage?
questions.answer: Pontine hemorrhage symptoms include sudden loss of consciousness, quadriplegia, pinpoint pupils, absent horizontal eye movements, irregular breathing, and brainstem hemorrhage with poor prognosis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of medullary syndrome?
questions.answer: Medullary syndrome symptoms include vertigo, nausea, vomiting, difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, loss of pain and temperature sensation, ataxia, and various syndromes depending on exact location.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome?
questions.answer: Lateral medullary syndrome symptoms include vertigo, nausea, vomiting, difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, loss of pain/temperature on same side face, opposite side body, ataxia, and Wallenberg syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of medial medullary syndrome?
questions.answer: Medial medullary syndrome symptoms include tongue deviation to affected side, weakness on opposite side of body, loss of position and vibration sense opposite side, and medial medulla infarction.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Dejerine syndrome?
questions.answer: Dejerine syndrome symptoms include weakness on one side, loss of position and vibration sense same side, and medial medullary syndrome affecting pyramid and medial lemniscus.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Wallenberg syndrome?
questions.answer: Wallenberg syndrome symptoms include vertigo, nystagmus, difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, facial numbness same side, loss of pain/temperature opposite side body, Horner syndrome, ataxia, and lateral medullary infarction.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of posterior inferior cerebellar artery stroke?
questions.answer: Posterior inferior cerebellar artery stroke symptoms include severe vertigo, vomiting, ataxia, difficulty swallowing, facial numbness, loss of pain/temperature sensation, and causes Wallenberg syndrome or cerebellar infarction.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anterior inferior cerebellar artery stroke?
questions.answer: Anterior inferior cerebellar artery stroke symptoms include vertigo, hearing loss, facial weakness, ataxia, loss of pain/temperature sensation, and involves lateral pons and cerebellum.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of superior cerebellar artery stroke?
questions.answer: Superior cerebellar artery stroke symptoms include severe ataxia, nausea and vomiting, dysarthria, loss of pain/temperature sensation, may have Horner syndrome, and affects superior cerebellum and midbrain.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of basilar artery thrombosis?
questions.answer: Basilar artery thrombosis symptoms include fluctuating consciousness, dizziness, double vision, dysarthria, weakness, ataxia, cranial nerve palsies, and medical emergency requiring urgent intervention.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of vertebral artery dissection?
questions.answer: Vertebral artery dissection symptoms include neck pain, headache (especially back of head), dizziness, double vision, loss of balance, stroke symptoms, and caused by tear in artery wall.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of carotid artery dissection?
questions.answer: Carotid artery dissection symptoms include neck pain, headache (especially around eye), drooping eyelid, small pupil (Horner syndrome), stroke symptoms, pulsatile tinnitus, and tear in carotid artery.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of fibromuscular dysplasia?
questions.answer: Fibromuscular dysplasia symptoms include high blood pressure, headaches, pulsatile tinnitus, dizziness, stroke or TIA, neck pain, and abnormal artery development causing narrowing or aneurysm.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Takayasu arteritis?
questions.answer: Takayasu arteritis symptoms include arm claudication, absent pulses, dizziness, fainting, vision changes, high blood pressure, fatigue, and inflammatory disease affecting aorta and its branches.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.answer: Polyarteritis nodosa symptoms include fever, weight loss, muscle pain, joint pain, skin lesions, abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, stroke, and vasculitis affecting medium-sized arteries.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Kawasaki disease?
questions.answer: Kawasaki disease symptoms include high fever lasting 5+ days, red eyes, red cracked lips, strawberry tongue, rash, swollen hands and feet, lymph node swelling, and childhood vasculitis affecting coronary arteries.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Henoch-Schönlein purpura?
questions.answer: Henoch-Schönlein purpura symptoms include purpuric rash on legs and buttocks, abdominal pain, joint pain, kidney involvement, and small vessel vasculitis most common in children.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Behçet's disease?
questions.answer: Behçet's disease symptoms include recurrent mouth ulcers, genital ulcers, eye inflammation, skin lesions, joint pain, neurological symptoms, vascular involvement, and multi-system inflammatory disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neuro-Behçet's disease?
questions.answer: Neuro-Behçet's disease symptoms include headache, meningoencephalitis, stroke, behavioral changes, cognitive impairment, brainstem symptoms, and nervous system involvement in Behçet's disease.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Susac syndrome?
questions.answer: Susac syndrome symptoms include encephalopathy, hearing loss, vision loss (branch retinal artery occlusions), headache, personality changes, and rare microangiopathy affecting brain, retina, and cochlea.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Sneddon syndrome?
questions.answer: Sneddon syndrome symptoms include livedo reticularis (net-like purple skin pattern), stroke, cognitive decline, high blood pressure, and non-inflammatory arteriopathy with antiphospholipid antibodies sometimes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of CADASIL?
questions.answer: CADASIL symptoms include migraine with aura (often starting in 20s-30s), recurrent strokes, mood disturbances, cognitive decline, seizures, and genetic small vessel disease causing dementia.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of CARASIL?
questions.answer: CARASIL symptoms include recurrent strokes in young adults, alopecia (hair loss), spondylosis (spine arthritis), and rare genetic small vessel disease similar to CADASIL.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Fabry disease neurological?
questions.answer: Fabry disease neurological symptoms include burning pain in hands and feet, stroke at young age, small vessel disease, hearing loss, and X-linked genetic disorder of lipid metabolism.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of homocystinuria neurological?
questions.answer: Homocystinuria neurological symptoms include intellectual disability, seizures, stroke at young age, psychiatric symptoms, and metabolic disorder causing elevated homocysteine and vascular disease.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of MELAS syndrome stroke?
questions.answer: MELAS syndrome stroke symptoms include stroke-like episodes not conforming to vascular territories, seizures, headaches, vomiting, lactic acidosis, and mitochondrial disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of antiphospholipid syndrome?
questions.answer: Antiphospholipid syndrome symptoms include blood clots (stroke, DVT, PE), recurrent miscarriages, livedo reticularis, low platelets, and autoimmune disorder causing hypercoagulability.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome?
questions.answer: Catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome symptoms include multiple organ thrombosis developing over days, kidney failure, respiratory failure, neurological symptoms, high mortality, and life-threatening complication.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.answer: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura symptoms include low platelets, hemolytic anemia, kidney problems, neurological symptoms (confusion, stroke, seizures), fever, and medical emergency requiring plasma exchange.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hemolytic uremic syndrome?
questions.answer: Hemolytic uremic syndrome symptoms include bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, hemolytic anemia, low platelets, kidney failure, neurological symptoms sometimes, and often follows E. coli infection in children.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of disseminated intravascular coagulation?
questions.answer: Disseminated intravascular coagulation symptoms include bleeding from multiple sites, bruising, organ dysfunction, confusion, low platelets, and life-threatening clotting and bleeding disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia?
questions.answer: Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia symptoms include thrombocytopenia during heparin therapy, blood clots (stroke, DVT, PE), skin necrosis at injection sites, and immune-mediated complication requiring heparin cessation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of protein C deficiency?
questions.answer: Protein C deficiency symptoms include recurrent blood clots (DVT, PE), stroke at young age, purpura fulminans in severe deficiency, and inherited or acquired hypercoagulable state.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of protein S deficiency?
questions.answer: Protein S deficiency symptoms include recurrent venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, stroke, and inherited or acquired anticoagulant protein deficiency increasing clot risk.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Factor V Leiden?
questions.answer: Factor V Leiden symptoms include increased risk of blood clots (DVT, PE), stroke sometimes, recurrent miscarriages, and most common inherited hypercoagulable disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of prothrombin gene mutation?
questions.answer: Prothrombin gene mutation symptoms include increased risk of venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, stroke sometimes, and second most common inherited hypercoagulable disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hyperhomocysteinemia?
questions.answer: Hyperhomocysteinemia symptoms include increased risk of vascular disease (stroke, heart attack), venous thrombosis, and elevated homocysteine from genetic or nutritional causes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of polycythemia vera?
questions.answer: Polycythemia vera symptoms include headache, dizziness, itching after bathing, red face, vision changes, blood clots (stroke), bleeding, enlarged spleen, and blood disorder with excess red blood cells.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of essential thrombocythemia?
questions.answer: Essential thrombocythemia symptoms include blood clots, bleeding, headache, dizziness, chest pain, numbness or tingling, and blood disorder with excess platelets.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sickle cell disease neurological?
questions.answer: Sickle cell disease neurological symptoms include stroke (especially children), TIA, seizures, headaches, cognitive problems, silent cerebral infarcts, and hemoglobin disorder causing vascular occlusion.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sickle cell crisis?
questions.answer: Sickle cell crisis symptoms include severe pain (bones, chest, abdomen), swelling in hands and feet, fever, jaundice, shortness of breath, and acute complication requiring emergency treatment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of thalassemia?
questions.answer: Thalassemia symptoms include anemia, fatigue, pale skin, jaundice, enlarged spleen, bone deformities, growth delays, and genetic disorder affecting hemoglobin production.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include hemolytic anemia triggered by infections, certain foods (fava beans), medications, jaundice, dark urine, and genetic enzyme deficiency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of pyruvate kinase deficiency?
questions.answer: Pyruvate kinase deficiency symptoms include chronic hemolytic anemia, jaundice, enlarged spleen, gallstones, fatigue, and genetic red blood cell enzyme deficiency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.answer: Hereditary spherocytosis symptoms include anemia, jaundice, enlarged spleen, gallstones, fatigue, and genetic disorder causing abnormal red blood cell shape leading to hemolysis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.answer: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria symptoms include dark urine (especially morning), anemia, fatigue, blood clots, abdominal pain, and rare acquired disorder causing complement-mediated hemolysis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of autoimmune hemolytic anemia?
questions.answer: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia symptoms include fatigue, pale skin, jaundice, dark urine, enlarged spleen, shortness of breath, and antibodies destroying own red blood cells.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of aplastic anemia?
questions.answer: Aplastic anemia symptoms include fatigue, weakness, pale skin, frequent infections, easy bruising and bleeding, prolonged bleeding, and bone marrow failure affecting all blood cell types.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of pernicious anemia?
questions.answer: Pernicious anemia symptoms include fatigue, weakness, pale skin, numbness or tingling in hands and feet, difficulty walking, memory problems, smooth red tongue, and autoimmune condition preventing B12 absorption.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of iron deficiency anemia?
questions.answer: Iron deficiency anemia symptoms include fatigue, weakness, pale skin, shortness of breath, cold hands and feet, brittle nails, unusual cravings (pica), restless legs, and most common anemia type.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of megaloblastic anemia?
questions.answer: Megaloblastic anemia symptoms include fatigue, weakness, pale or yellow skin, smooth red tongue, numbness or tingling, difficulty walking, memory problems, and caused by B12 or folate deficiency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anemia of chronic disease?
questions.answer: Anemia of chronic disease symptoms include fatigue, weakness, pale skin, develops with chronic infections, inflammatory conditions, cancer, or kidney disease, and mild to moderate anemia.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of myelodysplastic syndrome?
questions.answer: Myelodysplastic syndrome symptoms include fatigue, weakness, easy bruising and bleeding, frequent infections, shortness of breath, pale skin, and bone marrow disorder with abnormal blood cell production.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of acute myeloid leukemia?
questions.answer: Acute myeloid leukemia symptoms include fatigue, fever, frequent infections, easy bruising and bleeding, bone pain, weight loss, enlarged spleen or liver, and aggressive blood cancer.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
questions.answer: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia symptoms include fatigue, fever, easy bruising and bleeding, bone and joint pain, enlarged lymph nodes, enlarged liver or spleen, and most common childhood cancer.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of chronic myeloid leukemia?
questions.answer: Chronic myeloid leukemia symptoms include fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, fever, enlarged spleen, feeling full, bone pain, and chronic blood cancer with Philadelphia chromosome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of chronic lymphocytic leukemia?
questions.answer: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia symptoms include enlarged lymph nodes, fatigue, fever, night sweats, weight loss, frequent infections, and most common adult leukemia, often slow growing.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hairy cell leukemia?
questions.answer: Hairy cell leukemia symptoms include fatigue, weakness, frequent infections, enlarged spleen, easy bruising and bleeding, and rare slow-growing blood cancer with characteristic cell appearance.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Hodgkin lymphoma?
questions.answer: Hodgkin lymphoma symptoms include painless swollen lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, weight loss, itching, fatigue, chest pain or pressure, and cancer of lymphatic system.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of non-Hodgkin lymphoma?
questions.answer: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma symptoms include swollen lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, weight loss, fatigue, abdominal pain or swelling, chest pain, and diverse group of lymphatic cancers.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of multiple myeloma?
questions.answer: Multiple myeloma symptoms include bone pain, fractures, fatigue, frequent infections, weakness or numbness in legs, excessive thirst, nausea, and cancer of plasma cells in bone marrow.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia?
questions.answer: Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia symptoms include fatigue, weight loss, bleeding, vision problems, numbness in hands and feet, enlarged spleen or liver, and rare blood cancer with high IgM.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of POEMS syndrome?
questions.answer: POEMS syndrome symptoms include polyneuropathy, enlarged organs, endocrine changes, monoclonal protein, skin changes, weight loss, fatigue, and rare blood disorder affecting multiple systems.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of amyloidosis?
questions.answer: Amyloidosis symptoms include fatigue, weight loss, swelling in legs and ankles, shortness of breath, numbness or tingling, enlarged tongue, irregular heartbeat, and abnormal protein deposits in organs.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of AL amyloidosis?
questions.answer: AL amyloidosis symptoms include fatigue, weight loss, peripheral neuropathy, heart failure, kidney failure, enlarged tongue, purple patches around eyes, and light chain amyloid deposits.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of familial amyloid polyneuropathy?
questions.answer: Familial amyloid polyneuropathy symptoms include progressive peripheral neuropathy, autonomic dysfunction, cardiomyopathy, weight loss, and hereditary ATTR amyloidosis affecting nerves and organs.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cryoglobulinemia?
questions.answer: Cryoglobulinemia symptoms include purpura (purple spots on skin), joint pain, weakness, numbness or tingling, kidney problems, and abnormal proteins that precipitate in cold temperatures.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hyperviscosity syndrome?
questions.answer: Hyperviscosity syndrome symptoms include blurred vision, headache, dizziness, confusion, bleeding, shortness of breath, and thickened blood from excess proteins or blood cells.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration?
questions.answer: Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration symptoms include rapidly progressive ataxia, difficulty walking, slurred speech, double vision, nausea, dizziness, and immune attack on cerebellum associated with cancer.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis?
questions.answer: Paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis symptoms include memory loss, confusion, seizures, personality changes, difficulty walking, sensory loss, and immune attack on brain and spinal cord associated with cancer.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of limbic encephalitis?
questions.answer: Limbic encephalitis symptoms include memory loss, confusion, seizures, personality changes, hallucinations, sleep disturbances, and inflammation of limbic system, autoimmune or paraneoplastic.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis?
questions.answer: Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis symptoms include psychiatric symptoms, memory problems, seizures, abnormal movements, decreased consciousness, autonomic instability, and autoimmune encephalitis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anti-LGI1 encephalitis?
questions.answer: Anti-LGI1 encephalitis symptoms include faciobrachial dystonic seizures (brief facial and arm jerking), memory problems, confusion, hyponatremia, and autoimmune limbic encephalitis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anti-CASPR2 encephalitis?
questions.answer: Anti-CASPR2 encephalitis symptoms include encephalitis, peripheral nerve hyperexcitability (neuromyotonia), autonomic dysfunction, neuropathic pain, and autoimmune disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anti-GAD antibody syndrome?
questions.answer: Anti-GAD antibody syndrome symptoms include stiff person syndrome, cerebellar ataxia, limbic encephalitis, epilepsy, and autoimmune disorder with antibodies against GAD enzyme.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anti-amphiphysin syndrome?
questions.answer: Anti-amphiphysin syndrome symptoms include stiff person syndrome, encephalomyelitis, peripheral neuropathy, and paraneoplastic disorder often associated with breast or lung cancer.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome?
questions.answer: Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome symptoms include chaotic eye movements, myoclonus (muscle jerks), ataxia, behavioral changes, sleep disturbances, and paraneoplastic or post-infectious in children.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of paraneoplastic neuropathy?
questions.answer: Paraneoplastic neuropathy symptoms include numbness, tingling, weakness in limbs, burning pain, autonomic dysfunction, and immune-mediated nerve damage associated with cancer.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of paraneoplastic sensory neuronopathy?
