questions.answer: Paraneoplastic sensory neuronopathy symptoms include severe sensory loss, sensory ataxia, numbness and tingling, pain, and immune attack on dorsal root ganglia associated with small cell lung cancer.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome?
questions.answer: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome symptoms include muscle weakness (especially legs and hips), difficulty walking, dry mouth, erectile dysfunction, weakness improves with activity, and paraneoplastic disorder often with small cell lung cancer.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dermatomyositis?
questions.answer: Dermatomyositis symptoms include progressive muscle weakness, skin rash (purple around eyes, over knuckles), difficulty swallowing, muscle pain, fatigue, and inflammatory myopathy, may be paraneoplastic.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of polymyositis?
questions.answer: Polymyositis symptoms include progressive muscle weakness (especially shoulders and hips), difficulty climbing stairs, difficulty rising from chair, muscle pain, fatigue, and inflammatory myopathy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of inclusion body myositis?
questions.answer: Inclusion body myositis symptoms include slowly progressive weakness in quadriceps and finger flexors, difficulty walking, frequent falls, difficulty gripping, difficulty swallowing, and most common myopathy over age 50.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of necrotizing myopathy?
questions.answer: Necrotizing myopathy symptoms include rapidly progressive weakness, very high CK levels, muscle pain, difficulty walking, and immune-mediated muscle destruction, sometimes associated with statins or cancer.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of anti-synthetase syndrome?
questions.answer: Anti-synthetase syndrome symptoms include myositis, interstitial lung disease, arthritis, Raynaud's phenomenon, mechanic's hands, fever, and autoimmune disorder with anti-Jo-1 or other synthetase antibodies.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of overlap myositis?
questions.answer: Overlap myositis symptoms include myositis plus features of other connective tissue disease (scleroderma, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis), muscle weakness, skin changes, and overlapping autoimmune conditions.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus neurological?
questions.answer: Systemic lupus erythematosus neurological symptoms include headaches, seizures, stroke, cognitive dysfunction, psychosis, peripheral neuropathy, cranial neuropathies, and immune system attacking nervous system.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neuropsychiatric lupus?
questions.answer: Neuropsychiatric lupus symptoms include cognitive dysfunction, mood disorders, psychosis, seizures, headaches, stroke, peripheral neuropathy, and central and peripheral nervous system involvement in lupus.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Sjögren's syndrome neurological?
questions.answer: Sjögren's syndrome neurological symptoms include peripheral neuropathy, autonomic neuropathy, cranial neuropathies (especially trigeminal), CNS involvement (myelitis, encephalitis), and autoimmune disorder affecting nervous system.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis neurological?
questions.answer: Rheumatoid arthritis neurological symptoms include peripheral neuropathy, carpal tunnel syndrome, cervical myelopathy from spine instability, cranial nerve palsies, and nervous system complications of RA.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of mixed connective tissue disease?
questions.answer: Mixed connective tissue disease symptoms include features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, Raynaud's phenomenon, swollen hands, muscle weakness, joint pain, and overlap autoimmune disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of undifferentiated connective tissue disease?
questions.answer: Undifferentiated connective tissue disease symptoms include features suggesting connective tissue disease but not meeting criteria for specific disease, arthritis, Raynaud's, positive ANA, and may evolve into defined disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of relapsing polychondritis?
questions.answer: Relapsing polychondritis symptoms include recurrent inflammation of cartilage, red painful ears, hearing loss, saddle nose, joint pain, eye inflammation, and autoimmune disorder affecting cartilage throughout body.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sarcoidosis neurological?
questions.answer: Sarcoidosis neurological symptoms include cranial nerve palsies (especially facial), aseptic meningitis, seizures, cognitive problems, peripheral neuropathy, hypothalamic dysfunction, and granulomatous inflammation affecting nervous system.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurosarcoidosis facial nerve?
questions.answer: Neurosarcoidosis facial nerve symptoms include sudden facial weakness (like Bell's palsy), bilateral facial palsy sometimes, can be recurrent, and most common cranial nerve involved in neurosarcoidosis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurosarcoidosis meningeal?
questions.answer: Neurosarcoidosis meningeal symptoms include headache, neck stiffness, cranial nerve palsies, hydrocephalus, confusion, and granulomatous inflammation of meninges.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurosarcoidosis spinal cord?
questions.answer: Neurosarcoidosis spinal cord symptoms include weakness, sensory loss, bladder and bowel dysfunction, pain, and granulomatous inflammation or compression of spinal cord.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of granulomatosis with polyangiitis?
questions.answer: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis symptoms include sinus problems, nosebleeds, hearing loss, cough, kidney problems, peripheral neuropathy, skin lesions, and vasculitis affecting multiple organs.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis?
questions.answer: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis symptoms include asthma, sinus problems, peripheral neuropathy, skin lesions, heart involvement, and vasculitis with eosinophilia (Churg-Strauss syndrome).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of microscopic polyangiitis?
questions.answer: Microscopic polyangiitis symptoms include kidney failure, lung hemorrhage, peripheral neuropathy, skin lesions, joint pain, and small vessel vasculitis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes?
questions.answer: Cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes symptoms include recurrent fever, rash, joint pain, headache, hearing loss, eye inflammation, and autoinflammatory disorders caused by NLRP3 gene mutations.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of familial Mediterranean fever?
questions.answer: Familial Mediterranean fever symptoms include recurrent episodes of fever, abdominal pain, chest pain, joint pain, skin rash, and hereditary autoinflammatory disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome?
questions.answer: Tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome symptoms include recurrent fever lasting days to weeks, migratory muscle pain, skin rash, conjunctivitis, and hereditary autoinflammatory disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of mevalonate kinase deficiency?
questions.answer: Mevalonate kinase deficiency symptoms include recurrent fever, abdominal pain, joint pain, rash, hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delays, and hereditary autoinflammatory disorder (hyper-IgD syndrome).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of periodic fever syndromes?
questions.answer: Periodic fever syndromes symptoms include recurrent episodes of unexplained fever, varying associated symptoms (rash, joint pain, abdominal pain), and group of hereditary autoinflammatory disorders.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cyclic vomiting syndrome?
questions.answer: Cyclic vomiting syndrome symptoms include recurrent episodes of severe vomiting, nausea, lethargy, pallor, episodes last hours to days, wellness between episodes, and often associated with migraine.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of abdominal migraine?
questions.answer: Abdominal migraine symptoms include recurrent episodes of moderate to severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, pallor, headache may be absent, occurs in children, and migraine equivalent.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of benign paroxysmal vertigo of childhood?
questions.answer: Benign paroxysmal vertigo of childhood symptoms include brief episodes of vertigo, nystagmus, imbalance, anxiety, occurs in toddlers, no loss of consciousness, and migraine precursor.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of alternating hemiplegia of childhood?
questions.answer: Alternating hemiplegia of childhood symptoms include episodes of hemiplegia alternating sides, dystonia, seizures, developmental delays, triggered by stress or fatigue, and rare neurological disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of benign rolandic epilepsy?
questions.answer: Benign rolandic epilepsy symptoms include focal seizures involving face and mouth, occurs during sleep or upon waking, twitching, difficulty speaking, drooling, self-limited childhood epilepsy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of childhood absence epilepsy?
questions.answer: Childhood absence epilepsy symptoms include brief staring spells, loss of awareness for seconds, abrupt onset and offset, multiple episodes per day, normal development, and excellent prognosis with treatment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of juvenile absence epilepsy?
questions.answer: Juvenile absence epilepsy symptoms include absence seizures starting around puberty, may also have generalized tonic-clonic seizures, normal development, and requires long-term treatment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of benign infantile seizures?
questions.answer: Benign infantile seizures symptoms include brief focal or generalized seizures, clusters of seizures, onset in first year, normal development, spontaneous remission by age 2-3, and excellent prognosis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Panayiotopoulos syndrome?
questions.answer: Panayiotopoulos syndrome symptoms include seizures with autonomic features (vomiting, pallor, eye deviation), occurs during sleep, prolonged duration, benign childhood epilepsy syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Ohtahara syndrome?
questions.answer: Ohtahara syndrome symptoms include tonic spasms starting in first months of life, burst-suppression pattern on EEG, severe developmental delays, poor prognosis, and early infantile epileptic encephalopathy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of early myoclonic encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Early myoclonic encephalopathy symptoms include myoclonic seizures starting in first months, erratic myoclonus, burst-suppression on EEG, severe developmental impairment, and metabolic or genetic causes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of migrating partial seizures of infancy?
questions.answer: Migrating partial seizures of infancy symptoms include frequent focal seizures shifting between hemispheres, onset before 6 months, developmental regression, drug-resistant, and severe epileptic encephalopathy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of epilepsy with myoclonic-atonic seizures?
questions.answer: Epilepsy with myoclonic-atonic seizures symptoms include myoclonic-atonic seizures (sudden falls), absence seizures, developmental normal initially, variable outcome, and childhood epilepsy syndrome (Doose syndrome).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of epileptic encephalopathy with continuous spike-and-wave during sleep?
questions.answer: Epileptic encephalopathy with continuous spike-and-wave during sleep symptoms include cognitive and behavioral regression, seizures, continuous spike-wave on EEG during sleep, and requires aggressive treatment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of autosomal dominant nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy?
questions.answer: Autosomal dominant nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy symptoms include brief nocturnal seizures with bizarre movements, occurs in clusters, normal development, genetic disorder, and responds to treatment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of familial focal epilepsy with variable foci?
questions.answer: Familial focal epilepsy with variable foci symptoms include focal seizures with different localizations even within same family, generally benign, good response to treatment, and genetic epilepsy syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of generalized epilepsy with febrile seizures plus?
questions.answer: Generalized epilepsy with febrile seizures plus symptoms include febrile seizures persisting beyond age 6, afebrile seizures, multiple seizure types, normal development, and genetic epilepsy syndrome.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of progressive myoclonic epilepsy?
questions.answer: Progressive myoclonic epilepsy symptoms include myoclonic seizures, tonic-clonic seizures, progressive neurological decline, ataxia, dementia, and group of genetic disorders with poor prognosis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Unverricht-Lundborg disease?
questions.answer: Unverricht-Lundborg disease symptoms include myoclonic seizures starting in late childhood, tonic-clonic seizures, progressive ataxia, minimal cognitive decline, and most common progressive myoclonic epilepsy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Lafora disease?
questions.answer: Lafora disease symptoms include myoclonic seizures, visual hallucinations, rapid cognitive decline, ataxia, onset in adolescence, progressive and fatal, and progressive myoclonic epilepsy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis?
questions.answer: Neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis symptoms include vision loss, seizures, progressive cognitive and motor decline, ataxia, behavioral changes, and group of genetic lysosomal storage disorders (Batten disease).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sialidosis?
questions.answer: Sialidosis symptoms include myoclonus, cherry-red spot in eye, coarse features, skeletal abnormalities, cognitive decline, and lysosomal storage disorder with progressive myoclonic epilepsy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy?
questions.answer: Dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy symptoms include myoclonus, seizures, ataxia, choreoathetosis, dementia, behavioral changes, and hereditary neurodegenerative disorder (DRPLA).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers?
questions.answer: Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers symptoms include myoclonic seizures, ataxia, weakness, exercise intolerance, hearing loss, short stature, and mitochondrial disorder (MERRF syndrome).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of action myoclonus-renal failure syndrome?
questions.answer: Action myoclonus-renal failure syndrome symptoms include tremor, myoclonic seizures triggered by action, progressive renal failure, and rare genetic disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation?
questions.answer: Neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation symptoms include dystonia, parkinsonism, spasticity, cognitive decline, vision loss, and group of genetic disorders with iron accumulation in brain.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration?
questions.answer: Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration symptoms include dystonia, rigidity, choreoathetosis, cognitive decline, retinal degeneration, iron accumulation in brain, and most common NBIA disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of aceruloplasminemia?
questions.answer: Aceruloplasminemia symptoms include diabetes, retinal degeneration, neurological problems (ataxia, dystonia, cognitive decline), iron accumulation, and rare genetic disorder of iron and copper metabolism.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neuroferritinopathy?
questions.answer: Neuroferritinopathy symptoms include chorea, dystonia, parkinsonism, cognitive decline, iron accumulation in brain, and hereditary disorder of iron metabolism.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Kufor-Rakeb syndrome?
questions.answer: Kufor-Rakeb syndrome symptoms include early-onset parkinsonism, pyramidal signs, dementia, supranuclear gaze palsy, and rare genetic form of parkinsonism.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Woodhouse-Sakati syndrome?
questions.answer: Woodhouse-Sakati syndrome symptoms include hypogonadism, diabetes, alopecia, sensorineural hearing loss, extrapyramidal signs, and rare genetic disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Hallervorden-Spatz disease?
questions.answer: Hallervorden-Spatz disease symptoms include progressive dystonia, rigidity, choreoathetosis, cognitive decline, retinal degeneration, iron accumulation (eye of the tiger sign), and same as pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of biotin-thiamine-responsive basal ganglia disease?
questions.answer: Biotin-thiamine-responsive basal ganglia disease symptoms include encephalopathy, seizures, dystonia, confusion, coma triggered by febrile illness, and treatable with biotin and thiamine supplementation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Leigh syndrome variants?
questions.answer: Leigh syndrome variants symptoms include developmental regression, hypotonia, ataxia, dystonia, seizures, respiratory problems, feeding difficulties, and mitochondrial disorder with variable features.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of NARP syndrome?
questions.answer: NARP syndrome symptoms include neuropathy (sensory), ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, developmental delays, seizures, and mitochondrial disorder (neuropathy, ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of MNGIE syndrome?
questions.answer: MNGIE syndrome symptoms include gastrointestinal problems, cachexia, ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, peripheral neuropathy, leukoencephalopathy, and mitochondrial neurogastrointestinal encephalomyopathy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Alpers syndrome?
questions.answer: Alpers syndrome symptoms include seizures, developmental regression, liver failure, hypotonia, cortical blindness, and fatal mitochondrial disorder of childhood.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of POLG-related disorders?
questions.answer: POLG-related disorders symptoms include progressive external ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, neuropathy, seizures, liver disease, and mitochondrial DNA depletion syndromes caused by POLG mutations.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include developmental delays, seizures, ataxia, lactic acidosis, brain abnormalities, and metabolic disorder affecting energy production.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of complex I deficiency?
questions.answer: Complex I deficiency symptoms include leigh syndrome, cardiomyopathy, liver disease, lactic acidosis, developmental delays, and most common mitochondrial respiratory chain disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of complex IV deficiency?
questions.answer: Complex IV deficiency symptoms include leigh syndrome, cardiomyopathy, hepatopathy, renal tubular acidosis, muscle weakness, and mitochondrial respiratory chain disorder (cytochrome c oxidase deficiency).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of coenzyme Q10 deficiency?
questions.answer: Coenzyme Q10 deficiency symptoms include encephalomyopathy, ataxia, seizures, intellectual disability, nephrotic syndrome, cardiomyopathy, and treatable mitochondrial disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of mitochondrial DNA depletion syndromes?
questions.answer: Mitochondrial DNA depletion syndromes symptoms include severe myopathy, hepatopathy, encephalomyopathy, progressive weakness, liver failure, and genetic disorders reducing mitochondrial DNA content.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of respiratory chain disorders?
questions.answer: Respiratory chain disorders symptoms include muscle weakness, exercise intolerance, lactic acidosis, cardiomyopathy, seizures, developmental delays, multi-organ involvement, and mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation defects.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Barth syndrome?
questions.answer: Barth syndrome symptoms include cardiomyopathy, muscle weakness, neutropenia, growth delays, fatigue, and X-linked genetic disorder affecting cardiolipin synthesis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Pearson syndrome?
questions.answer: Pearson syndrome symptoms include severe anemia, pancreatic insufficiency, failure to thrive, lactic acidosis, can evolve into Kearns-Sayre syndrome, and mitochondrial disorder of infancy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia plus?
questions.answer: Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia plus symptoms include ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, plus additional features (muscle weakness, neuropathy, ataxia, cardiac conduction defects), and mitochondrial disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sensory ataxic neuropathy with dysarthria and ophthalmoplegia?
questions.answer: Sensory ataxic neuropathy with dysarthria and ophthalmoplegia symptoms include sensory ataxia, dysarthria, ophthalmoplegia, neuropathy, and mitochondrial disorder (SANDO syndrome).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of myoclonic epilepsy myopathy sensory ataxia?
questions.answer: Myoclonic epilepsy myopathy sensory ataxia symptoms include myoclonic seizures, muscle weakness, sensory ataxia, hearing loss, and mitochondrial disorder (MEMSA syndrome).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of leber hereditary optic neuropathy?
questions.answer: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy symptoms include painless bilateral vision loss (subacute), central scotomas, color vision defects, affects young adult males primarily, and mitochondrial disorder causing optic nerve degeneration.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dominant optic atrophy?
questions.answer: Dominant optic atrophy symptoms include gradual bilateral vision loss, color vision defects, central scotomas, optic disc pallor, onset in childhood, and genetic disorder (OPA1 gene).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Wolfram syndrome?
questions.answer: Wolfram syndrome symptoms include diabetes insipidus, diabetes mellitus, optic atrophy, deafness (DIDMOAD), neurological problems, and rare genetic disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hereditary spastic paraplegia?
questions.answer: Hereditary spastic paraplegia symptoms include progressive leg stiffness and weakness, spasticity, brisk reflexes, difficulty walking, urinary urgency, and group of genetic disorders.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of complicated hereditary spastic paraplegia?
questions.answer: Complicated hereditary spastic paraplegia symptoms include spastic paraplegia plus additional features (cognitive impairment, peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, seizures, vision problems), and genetic disorders with broader involvement.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of spastic ataxia?
questions.answer: Spastic ataxia symptoms include combination of spasticity and ataxia, gait difficulties, dysarthria, eye movement abnormalities, and overlapping syndrome seen in various genetic disorders.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Troyer syndrome?
questions.answer: Troyer syndrome symptoms include spastic paraplegia, distal muscle wasting, developmental delays, short stature, and recessive form of complicated hereditary spastic paraplegia.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Sjögren-Larsson syndrome?
questions.answer: Sjögren-Larsson syndrome symptoms include ichthyosis (scaly skin), spastic diplegia, intellectual disability, retinal changes, and genetic disorder of fatty aldehyde metabolism.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome?
questions.answer: Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome symptoms include severe intellectual disability, hypotonia evolving to spasticity, poor head control, dystonia, and X-linked disorder of thyroid hormone transport.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy childhood form?
questions.answer: X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy childhood form symptoms include behavioral changes, declining school performance, vision and hearing loss, seizures, spasticity, dementia, and rapidly progressive demyelination.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of adrenomyeloneuropathy?
questions.answer: Adrenomyeloneuropathy symptoms include progressive spastic paraparesis, peripheral neuropathy, adrenal insufficiency, urinary problems, slower progression than childhood ALD, and adult-onset form of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts?
questions.answer: Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts symptoms include migraine with aura, recurrent strokes, mood disturbances, cognitive decline, seizures, and genetic small vessel disease (CADASIL).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cerebral autosomal recessive arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts?
questions.answer: Cerebral autosomal recessive arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts symptoms include young-onset stroke, cognitive decline, mood disturbances, alopecia, spondylosis, and genetic small vessel disease (CARASIL).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of COL4A1-related disorders?
questions.answer: COL4A1-related disorders symptoms include porencephaly, intracerebral hemorrhage, small vessel disease, eye abnormalities, kidney disease, and genetic collagen disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cathepsin A deficiency?
questions.answer: Cathepsin A deficiency symptoms include myoclonus, seizures, cherry-red spot, ataxia, dysmorphic features, and lysosomal storage disorder (galactosialidosis).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of GM1 gangliosidosis?
questions.answer: GM1 gangliosidosis symptoms include developmental regression, seizures, hepatosplenomegaly, cherry-red spot, skeletal abnormalities, and lysosomal storage disorder with varying ages of onset.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of GM2 gangliosidosis?
questions.answer: GM2 gangliosidosis symptoms include developmental regression, seizures, cherry-red spot, loss of motor skills, blindness, and includes Tay-Sachs and Sandhoff disease.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Sandhoff disease?
questions.answer: Sandhoff disease symptoms include developmental regression, seizures, cherry-red spot, loss of motor skills, organomegaly, and GM2 gangliosidosis similar to Tay-Sachs but with visceral involvement.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Krabbe disease infantile form?
questions.answer: Krabbe disease infantile form symptoms include irritability, feeding difficulties, developmental regression, hypertonia, seizures, blindness, deafness, and rapidly progressive leukodystrophy.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Krabbe disease late-onset?
questions.answer: Krabbe disease late-onset symptoms include vision loss, weakness, difficulty walking, peripheral neuropathy, slower progression than infantile form, and leukodystrophy presenting in childhood or adulthood.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of metachromatic leukodystrophy late infantile?
questions.answer: Metachromatic leukodystrophy late infantile symptoms include gait difficulties, developmental regression, hypotonia evolving to spasticity, loss of speech, seizures, and most common form.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of metachromatic leukodystrophy juvenile?
questions.answer: Metachromatic leukodystrophy juvenile symptoms include declining school performance, behavioral problems, gait difficulties, cognitive decline, slower progression than late infantile form.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of metachromatic leukodystrophy adult?
questions.answer: Metachromatic leukodystrophy adult symptoms include psychiatric symptoms, cognitive decline, gait difficulties, peripheral neuropathy, slowest progression, and may mimic psychiatric disorders.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of globoid cell leukodystrophy?
questions.answer: Globoid cell leukodystrophy symptoms include irritability, developmental regression, seizures, vision and hearing loss, hypertonia, and same as Krabbe disease.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Refsum disease?
questions.answer: Refsum disease symptoms include retinitis pigmentosa, peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, hearing loss, anosmia, cardiac problems, and peroxisomal disorder of phytanic acid metabolism.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Zellweger syndrome?
questions.answer: Zellweger syndrome symptoms include severe hypotonia, seizures, craniofacial abnormalities, liver disease, kidney cysts, skeletal abnormalities, and severe peroxisomal biogenesis disorder with poor prognosis.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy?
questions.answer: Neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy symptoms include hypotonia, seizures, developmental delays, vision and hearing impairment, adrenal insufficiency, and peroxisomal disorder intermediate in severity.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of infantile Refsum disease?
questions.answer: Infantile Refsum disease symptoms include developmental delays, retinopathy, hearing loss, liver disease, hypotonia, and peroxisomal disorder distinct from classic adult Refsum disease.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata?
questions.answer: Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata symptoms include shortened limbs, cataracts, skeletal abnormalities, intellectual disability, seizures, and peroxisomal disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis?
questions.answer: Cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis symptoms include tendon xanthomas, cataracts, chronic diarrhea, ataxia, spasticity, cognitive decline, and sterol metabolism disorder treatable with chenodeoxycholic acid.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Niemann-Pick disease type A?
questions.answer: Niemann-Pick disease type A symptoms include developmental regression, hepatosplenomegaly, cherry-red spot, feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, and severe infantile neurovisceral lipid storage disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Niemann-Pick disease type C?
questions.answer: Niemann-Pick disease type C symptoms include vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, ataxia, dystonia, seizures, cognitive decline, hepatosplenomegaly, and cholesterol trafficking disorder with variable age of onset.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Pompe disease infantile?
questions.answer: Pompe disease infantile symptoms include severe muscle weakness, enlarged heart, breathing difficulties, feeding problems, enlarged tongue, and glycogen storage disease with poor prognosis without treatment.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Pompe disease late-onset?
questions.answer: Pompe disease late-onset symptoms include progressive muscle weakness, respiratory insufficiency, difficulty walking, back pain, and glycogen storage disease presenting in childhood or adulthood.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Danon disease?
questions.answer: Danon disease symptoms include cardiomyopathy, skeletal myopathy, intellectual disability, retinopathy, and lysosomal glycogen storage disorder (LAMP2 deficiency).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of McArdle disease?
questions.answer: McArdle disease symptoms include exercise intolerance, muscle cramps and pain with exercise, second wind phenomenon, myoglobinuria, and glycogen storage disease (muscle phosphorylase deficiency).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Tarui disease?
questions.answer: Tarui disease symptoms include exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria, hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and glycogen storage disease (phosphofructokinase deficiency).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of glycogen storage disease type III?
questions.answer: Glycogen storage disease type III symptoms include hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, growth delays, muscle weakness, cardiomyopathy in some, and debrancher enzyme deficiency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of glycogen storage disease type IV?
questions.answer: Glycogen storage disease type IV symptoms include liver cirrhosis, hepatosplenomegaly, failure to thrive, muscle weakness, cardiomyopathy, and branching enzyme deficiency with variable presentations.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of glycogen storage disease type V?
questions.answer: Glycogen storage disease type V symptoms include exercise intolerance, muscle cramps and pain, myoglobinuria, second wind phenomenon, and same as McArdle disease (muscle phosphorylase deficiency).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of lactate dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Lactate dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria, skin rashes sometimes, and glycogen storage disease type XI.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of phosphoglycerate kinase deficiency?
questions.answer: Phosphoglycerate kinase deficiency symptoms include exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria, hemolytic anemia, neurological problems in some, and X-linked glycogen storage disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of phosphoglycerate mutase deficiency?
questions.answer: Phosphoglycerate mutase deficiency symptoms include exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria, and rare glycogen storage disease type X.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of aldolase A deficiency?
questions.answer: Aldolase A deficiency symptoms include exercise intolerance, muscle weakness, hemolytic anemia, developmental delays, and rare glycogen storage disease type XII.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of beta-enolase deficiency?
questions.answer: Beta-enolase deficiency symptoms include exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria, and rare glycogen storage disease type XIII.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency?
questions.answer: Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency symptoms include exercise-induced muscle pain and weakness, myoglobinuria, triggered by prolonged exercise or fasting, and fatty acid oxidation disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of very long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Very long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include hypoglycemia, liver disease, cardiomyopathy, muscle weakness, rhabdomyolysis, and fatty acid oxidation disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include hypoglycemia, vomiting, lethargy, seizures triggered by fasting or illness, and most common fatty acid oxidation disorder (MCAD deficiency).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include developmental delays, muscle weakness, hypotonia, feeding difficulties, and fatty acid oxidation disorder (SCAD deficiency).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of multiple acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Multiple acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, muscle weakness, cardiomyopathy, liver disease, and glutaric aciduria type II.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of carnitine deficiency?
questions.answer: Carnitine deficiency symptoms include muscle weakness, cardiomyopathy, hypoglycemia, liver disease, developmental delays, and primary or secondary deficiency of carnitine.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase deficiency?
questions.answer: Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase deficiency symptoms include severe hypoglycemia, cardiomyopathy, liver disease, muscle weakness, arrhythmias, and life-threatening fatty acid oxidation disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of carnitine palmitoyltransferase I deficiency?
questions.answer: Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I deficiency symptoms include hypoglycemia, liver disease, no muscle involvement typically, triggered by fasting, and fatty acid oxidation disorder (CPT1 deficiency).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of electron transfer flavoprotein deficiency?
questions.answer: Electron transfer flavoprotein deficiency symptoms include hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, muscle weakness, cardiomyopathy, and multiple acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (glutaric aciduria type II).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of riboflavin-responsive multiple acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Riboflavin-responsive multiple acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include muscle weakness, exercise intolerance, lipid storage myopathy, responds to riboflavin supplementation, and late-onset milder form.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neutral lipid storage disease with myopathy?
questions.answer: Neutral lipid storage disease with myopathy symptoms include progressive muscle weakness, muscle atrophy, elevated CK, lipid droplets in muscles, cardiomyopathy sometimes, and genetic lipid metabolism disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of neutral lipid storage disease with ichthyosis?
questions.answer: Neutral lipid storage disease with ichthyosis symptoms include ichthyosis (scaly skin), myopathy, liver disease, hearing loss, short stature, and genetic lipid metabolism disorder (Chanarin-Dorfman syndrome).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of glutaric aciduria type I?
questions.answer: Glutaric aciduria type I symptoms include macrocephaly, movement disorder (dystonia, choreoathetosis), encephalopathic crises, developmental regression, and organic acid disorder treatable with dietary restriction.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of propionic acidemia?
questions.answer: Propionic acidemia symptoms include vomiting, lethargy, developmental delays, metabolic acidosis, hyperammonemia, cardiomyopathy, movement disorders, and organic acid disorder requiring dietary management.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of methylmalonic acidemia?
questions.answer: Methylmalonic acidemia symptoms include vomiting, dehydration, hypotonia, developmental delays, metabolic acidosis, hyperammonemia, failure to thrive, and organic acid disorder, some forms B12-responsive.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of isovaleric acidemia?
questions.answer: Isovaleric acidemia symptoms include vomiting, lethargy, seizures, metabolic acidosis, distinctive sweaty feet odor, and organic acid disorder responsive to dietary management and carnitine.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency?
questions.answer: 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency symptoms include hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, developmental delays, feeding difficulties, many asymptomatic, and leucine metabolism disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaric aciduria?
questions.answer: 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaric aciduria symptoms include hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, Reye-like syndrome, many asymptomatic, and leucine metabolism disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of 3-methylglutaconic aciduria?
questions.answer: 3-methylglutaconic aciduria symptoms vary by type, including cardiomyopathy, neutropenia, neurological problems, movement disorders, and multiple genetic causes.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Barth syndrome cardiomyopathy?
questions.answer: Barth syndrome cardiomyopathy symptoms include dilated cardiomyopathy, heart failure, arrhythmias, muscle weakness, neutropenia, and 3-methylglutaconic aciduria type II.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of Costeff syndrome?
questions.answer: Costeff syndrome symptoms include optic atrophy, movement disorder (especially dystonia), cognitive impairment, and 3-methylglutaconic aciduria type III.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of DCMA syndrome?
questions.answer: DCMA syndrome symptoms include dilated cardiomyopathy, cerebellar ataxia, testicular dysgenesis, and 3-methylglutaconic aciduria type V.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of malonic aciduria?
questions.answer: Malonic aciduria symptoms include developmental delays, seizures, hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, cardiomyopathy, and malonyl-CoA decarboxylase deficiency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of ethylmalonic encephalopathy?
questions.answer: Ethylmalonic encephalopathy symptoms include developmental delays, seizures, pyramidal signs, acrocyanosis, chronic diarrhea, petechiae, and progressive neurodegenerative disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of combined malonic and methylmalonic aciduria?
questions.answer: Combined malonic and methylmalonic aciduria symptoms include developmental delays, hypotonia, metabolic acidosis, developmental regression, and ACSF3 deficiency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of multiple carboxylase deficiency?
questions.answer: Multiple carboxylase deficiency symptoms include metabolic acidosis, skin rash, alopecia, seizures, developmental delays, and biotinidase deficiency or holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency, treatable with biotin.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of biotinidase deficiency?
questions.answer: Biotinidase deficiency symptoms include seizures, hypotonia, skin rash, alopecia, hearing loss, vision problems, developmental delays, and treatable with biotin supplementation if caught early.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency?
questions.answer: Holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency symptoms include vomiting, hypotonia, seizures, skin rash, metabolic acidosis, developmental delays, and early-onset multiple carboxylase deficiency treatable with biotin.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of 2-methylbutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: 2-methylbutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include developmental delays, seizures, dystonia, many asymptomatic, and isoleucine metabolism disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of isobutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Isobutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include cardiomyopathy, anemia, developmental delays, many asymptomatic, and valine metabolism disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of short branched-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Short branched-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include developmental delays, seizures, hypotonia, metabolic acidosis, and branched-chain amino acid metabolism disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of 2-methyl-3-hydroxybutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: 2-methyl-3-hydroxybutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include metabolic decompensation, developmental delays, cardiomyopathy, and isoleucine metabolism disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of beta-ketothiolase deficiency?
questions.answer: Beta-ketothiolase deficiency symptoms include episodic metabolic acidosis, vomiting, lethargy, developmental delays between episodes, and isoleucine metabolism disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase deficiency?
questions.answer: Succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase deficiency symptoms include severe ketoacidosis, vomiting, lethargy, developmental delays, and ketone body utilization disorder (SCOT deficiency).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of HMG-CoA lyase deficiency?
questions.answer: HMG-CoA lyase deficiency symptoms include hypoketotic hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, and ketogenesis disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of HMG-CoA synthase deficiency?
questions.answer: HMG-CoA synthase deficiency symptoms include hypoketotic hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, encephalopathy, triggered by fasting or illness, and ketogenesis disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of mitochondrial acetoacetyl-CoA thiolase deficiency?
questions.answer: Mitochondrial acetoacetyl-CoA thiolase deficiency symptoms include metabolic acidosis, ketoacidosis, developmental delays, and same as beta-ketothiolase deficiency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of cytosolic acetoacetyl-CoA thiolase deficiency?
questions.answer: Cytosolic acetoacetyl-CoA thiolase deficiency symptoms include developmental delays, intellectual disability, and alpha-methylacetoacetic aciduria.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of tyrosinemia type I?
questions.answer: Tyrosinemia type I symptoms include liver failure, kidney problems, neurological crises (porphyria-like), cabbage-like odor, and tyrosine metabolism disorder treatable with nitisinone.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of tyrosinemia type II?
questions.answer: Tyrosinemia type II symptoms include eye problems (corneal lesions, photophobia), skin lesions (palms and soles), developmental delays sometimes, and tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of tyrosinemia type III?
questions.answer: Tyrosinemia type III symptoms include intellectual disability, seizures, ataxia, and 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase deficiency, rare disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of alkaptonuria?
questions.answer: Alkaptonuria symptoms include dark urine (upon standing), ochronosis (dark pigmentation of tissues), arthritis (especially spine and large joints), heart valve disease, and tyrosine metabolism disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of hawkinsinuria?
questions.answer: Hawkinsinuria symptoms include metabolic acidosis in infancy, failure to thrive, usually improves with age, and rare tyrosine metabolism disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of aromatic L-amino acid decarboxylase deficiency?
questions.answer: Aromatic L-amino acid decarboxylase deficiency symptoms include severe developmental delays, hypotonia, movement disorder, oculogyric crises, autonomic dysfunction, and neurotransmitter synthesis disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of sepiapterin reductase deficiency?
questions.answer: Sepiapterin reductase deficiency symptoms include dystonia, parkinsonism, intellectual disability, oculomotor apraxia, sleep disturbances, and tetrahydrobiopterin synthesis disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency?
questions.answer: Tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency symptoms include hyperphenylalaninemia, developmental delays, movement disorders, seizures, intellectual disability, and requires BH4 and neurotransmitter supplementation.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of dopamine beta-hydroxylase deficiency?
questions.answer: Dopamine beta-hydroxylase deficiency symptoms include orthostatic hypotension, ptosis, exercise intolerance, nasal congestion, and norepinephrine synthesis disorder.

questions.question: What are the symptoms of monoamine oxidase A deficiency?
questions.answer: Monoamine oxidase A deficiency symptoms include intellectual disability, impulsive aggression, behavioral problems, stereotypic hand movements, and X-linked disorder (Brunner syndrome).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency?
questions.answer: Succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency symptoms include developmental delays, hypotonia, ataxia, seizures, behavioral problems, intellectual disability, and GABA metabolism disorder.

questions.question: How does migraine present?
questions.answer: Migraine presents with severe throbbing headache (usually one-sided), nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, visual aura in some cases, and episodes lasting 4-72 hours with significant disability during attacks.

questions.question: How does stroke present?
questions.answer: Stroke presents with sudden onset of focal neurological deficits including facial drooping, arm weakness, speech difficulties, numbness on one side, vision loss, confusion, severe headache, and difficulty walking or maintaining balance.

questions.question: How does Alzheimer's disease present?
questions.answer: Alzheimer's disease presents with gradual memory loss (especially recent events), difficulty with familiar tasks, language problems, disorientation, poor judgment, personality changes, and progressive cognitive decline interfering with daily life.

questions.question: How does Parkinson's disease present?
questions.answer: Parkinson's disease presents with resting tremor (often starting in one hand), bradykinesia (slowness of movement), muscle rigidity, postural instability, shuffling gait, reduced facial expression, and symptoms typically start unilaterally.

questions.question: How does epilepsy present?
questions.answer: Epilepsy presents with recurrent unprovoked seizures which may include loss of consciousness, convulsions, staring spells, unusual sensations, confusion, or focal motor/sensory symptoms depending on seizure type and brain location affected.

questions.question: How does brain tumor present?
questions.answer: Brain tumor presents with progressive headaches (worse in morning), new-onset seizures, focal neurological deficits, personality changes, cognitive problems, nausea and vomiting, and symptoms vary based on tumor location and size.

questions.question: How does meningitis present?
questions.answer: Meningitis presents acutely with high fever, severe headache, stiff neck (nuchal rigidity), photophobia, nausea and vomiting, altered mental status, and may include petechial rash in meningococcal cases.

questions.question: How does multiple sclerosis present?
questions.answer: Multiple sclerosis presents with episodes of neurological dysfunction including optic neuritis (vision loss), sensory symptoms, weakness, Lhermitte's sign (electric sensation down spine), ataxia, bladder problems, and symptoms vary by lesion location.

questions.question: How does brain aneurysm rupture present?
questions.answer: Brain aneurysm rupture presents with sudden thunderclap headache (worst headache of life), nausea and vomiting, loss of consciousness, stiff neck, vision changes, seizures, and constitutes a neurological emergency.

questions.question: How does dementia present?
questions.answer: Dementia presents with progressive cognitive decline affecting memory, language, executive function, and activities of daily living, along with behavioral changes, personality changes, and loss of independence over time.

questions.question: How does tension headache present?
questions.answer: Tension headache presents with bilateral band-like pressure or tightness around head, mild to moderate intensity, no nausea or vomiting, may have scalp tenderness, and typically not worsened by physical activity.

questions.question: How does concussion present?
questions.answer: Concussion presents after head trauma with headache, confusion, dizziness, nausea, balance problems, sensitivity to light and noise, difficulty concentrating, memory problems, and symptoms may appear immediately or develop over hours.

questions.question: How does depression present?
questions.answer: Depression presents with persistent low mood, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, changes in appetite and sleep, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, and sometimes suicidal thoughts.

questions.question: How does anxiety disorder present?
questions.answer: Anxiety disorder presents with excessive worry that's difficult to control, restlessness, fatigue, poor concentration, irritability, muscle tension, sleep disturbances, and may include panic attacks with physical symptoms.

questions.question: How does insomnia present?
questions.answer: Insomnia presents with difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep, early morning awakening, daytime fatigue, irritability, difficulty concentrating, impaired performance, and symptoms lasting at least three nights per week for three months.

questions.question: How does cluster headache present?
questions.answer: Cluster headache presents with severe unilateral orbital or temporal pain occurring in clusters, associated with ipsilateral autonomic features (tearing, nasal congestion, eyelid swelling), restlessness, and attacks lasting 15-180 minutes.

questions.question: How does Bell's palsy present?
questions.answer: Bell's palsy presents with sudden onset unilateral facial weakness or paralysis, inability to close eye, drooping mouth corner, loss of taste, pain behind ear, and hyperacusis on affected side.

questions.question: How does traumatic brain injury present?
questions.answer: Traumatic brain injury presents with headache, confusion, memory problems, dizziness, nausea, sensitivity to light and sound, mood changes, sleep disturbances, and severity varies from mild concussion to severe injury with loss of consciousness.

questions.question: How does encephalitis present?
questions.answer: Encephalitis presents with fever, headache, altered mental status, confusion, personality changes, seizures, focal neurological deficits, and may progress rapidly to coma, constituting a medical emergency.

questions.question: How does Huntington's disease present?
questions.answer: Huntington's disease presents with involuntary choreiform movements, personality changes, irritability, depression, cognitive decline, difficulty with coordination and balance, and typically manifests in middle age with progressive worsening.

questions.question: How does ALS present?
questions.answer: ALS presents with progressive muscle weakness and atrophy, starting focally (often in hands or feet), fasciculations, muscle cramps, difficulty speaking or swallowing, and eventual respiratory involvement with preserved cognition in most cases.

questions.question: How does narcolepsy present?
questions.answer: Narcolepsy presents with excessive daytime sleepiness, sudden uncontrollable sleep attacks, cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone with emotions), sleep paralysis, hypnagogic hallucinations, and disrupted nighttime sleep.

questions.question: How does sleep apnea present?
questions.answer: Sleep apnea presents with loud snoring, witnessed apneas, gasping or choking during sleep, excessive daytime sleepiness, morning headaches, difficulty concentrating, irritability, and unrefreshing sleep.

questions.question: How does vertigo present?
questions.answer: Vertigo presents with illusion of movement (spinning sensation), imbalance, nausea and vomiting, nystagmus, difficulty standing or walking, and may be triggered by head position changes depending on underlying cause.

questions.question: How does peripheral neuropathy present?
questions.answer: Peripheral neuropathy presents with numbness and tingling in distal extremities (glove-and-stocking distribution), burning or shooting pain, sensitivity to touch, muscle weakness, loss of coordination, and may affect autonomic functions.

questions.question: How does brain hemorrhage present?
questions.answer: Brain hemorrhage presents with sudden severe headache, vomiting, altered consciousness, focal neurological deficits, seizures, neck stiffness if subarachnoid, and symptoms depend on location and size of bleeding.

questions.question: How does cerebral palsy present?
questions.answer: Cerebral palsy presents with abnormal muscle tone, delayed motor milestones, abnormal posture and movements, difficulty with fine motor skills, balance problems, speech difficulties, and symptoms vary widely in severity and distribution.

questions.question: How does hydrocephalus present?
questions.answer: Hydrocephalus presents differently by age - in infants with enlarged head, bulging fontanel, vomiting; in older individuals with headache, nausea, vision problems, gait disturbance, cognitive decline, and urinary incontinence.

questions.question: How does Tourette syndrome present?
questions.answer: Tourette syndrome presents with multiple motor tics and at least one vocal tic, occurring before age 18, tics wax and wane, temporarily suppressible, preceded by premonitory urge, and often associated with ADHD or OCD.

questions.question: How does trigeminal neuralgia present?
questions.answer: Trigeminal neuralgia presents with sudden severe electric shock-like facial pain in trigeminal nerve distribution, triggered by light touch, talking, chewing, or cold air, lasting seconds to minutes, with pain-free intervals between attacks.

questions.question: How does restless leg syndrome present?
questions.answer: Restless leg syndrome presents with uncomfortable sensations in legs (crawling, tingling, aching), irresistible urge to move legs, symptoms worse at rest and in evening/night, relief with movement, and disrupted sleep.

questions.question: How does PTSD present?
questions.answer: PTSD presents with intrusive memories of traumatic event, flashbacks, nightmares, avoidance of trauma reminders, negative mood changes, hyperarousal, exaggerated startle response, difficulty concentrating, and symptoms lasting more than one month.

questions.question: How does OCD present?
questions.answer: OCD presents with recurrent intrusive obsessive thoughts causing anxiety, followed by repetitive compulsive behaviors or mental acts to reduce distress, recognition that obsessions are excessive, significant time consumption, and functional impairment.

questions.question: How does schizophrenia present?
questions.answer: Schizophrenia presents with positive symptoms (hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech), negative symptoms (flat affect, social withdrawal, lack of motivation), cognitive impairment, and typically emerges in late adolescence or early adulthood.

questions.question: How does bipolar disorder present?
questions.answer: Bipolar disorder presents with mood episodes alternating between mania (elevated mood, increased energy, decreased need for sleep, impulsivity) and depression (low mood, loss of interest, fatigue), with varying cycle lengths and severity.

questions.question: How does autism spectrum disorder present?
questions.answer: Autism spectrum disorder presents with social communication difficulties, restricted repetitive behaviors and interests, sensory sensitivities, preference for routine, difficulty with social reciprocity, and symptoms present from early development with varying severity.

questions.question: How does ADHD present?
questions.answer: ADHD presents with inattention (difficulty focusing, easily distracted, forgetfulness), hyperactivity (fidgeting, restlessness, excessive talking), impulsivity (acting without thinking, interrupting), and symptoms present before age 12 in multiple settings.

questions.question: How does brain abscess present?
questions.answer: Brain abscess presents with progressive headache, fever, focal neurological deficits, altered mental status, seizures, nausea and vomiting, and symptoms develop over days to weeks with signs of increased intracranial pressure.

questions.question: How does transient ischemic attack present?
questions.answer: Transient ischemic attack presents with sudden focal neurological deficits identical to stroke but resolving completely within 24 hours (typically within minutes), including weakness, numbness, speech problems, vision loss, or dizziness.

questions.question: How does Guillain-Barré syndrome present?
questions.answer: Guillain-Barré syndrome presents with rapidly progressive ascending weakness starting in legs, areflexia, sensory symptoms, facial weakness, autonomic dysfunction, and may progress to respiratory failure requiring ventilation within days to weeks.

questions.question: How does myasthenia gravis present?
questions.answer: Myasthenia gravis presents with fluctuating muscle weakness worsening with activity and improving with rest, commonly affecting ocular muscles (ptosis, diplopia), bulbar muscles (dysarthria, dysphagia), and limb muscles.

questions.question: How does Chiari malformation present?
questions.answer: Chiari malformation presents with headaches (worse with coughing or straining), neck pain, balance problems, dizziness, numbness and tingling, difficulty swallowing, vision problems, and syringomyelia symptoms in some cases.

questions.question: How does chronic fatigue syndrome present?
questions.answer: Chronic fatigue syndrome presents with severe debilitating fatigue lasting at least 6 months, post-exertional malaise, unrefreshing sleep, cognitive difficulties (brain fog), orthostatic intolerance, muscle and joint pain.

questions.question: How does fibromyalgia present?
questions.answer: Fibromyalgia presents with widespread chronic pain, tender points, fatigue, unrefreshing sleep, cognitive difficulties (fibro fog), headaches, morning stiffness, and symptoms exacerbated by stress, weather changes, or activity.

questions.question: How does dystonia present?
questions.answer: Dystonia presents with sustained or intermittent involuntary muscle contractions causing abnormal postures, twisting movements, or tremor, may be focal (affecting one body part) or generalized, and worsens with voluntary movement or stress.

questions.question: How does essential tremor present?
questions.answer: Essential tremor presents with bilateral action tremor (most noticeable with hands outstretched or during tasks), may affect head or voice, worsens with stress or fatigue, improves with alcohol, and slowly progressive over years.

questions.question: How does temporal arteritis present?
questions.answer: Temporal arteritis presents in elderly with new-onset severe headache (temporal region), scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, vision changes or sudden vision loss, fever, malaise, shoulder and hip pain, and elevated inflammatory markers.

questions.question: How does normal pressure hydrocephalus present?
questions.answer: Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with classic triad of gait disturbance (magnetic gait), urinary incontinence, and dementia, with insidious onset in elderly and potential reversibility with shunt placement.

questions.question: How does progressive supranuclear palsy present?
questions.answer: Progressive supranuclear palsy presents with early falls, vertical supranuclear gaze palsy (especially downward gaze), axial rigidity, pseudobulbar palsy, cognitive decline, and poor response to levodopa.

questions.question: How does Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease present?
questions.answer: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease presents with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, visual disturbances, ataxia, akinetic mutism, and progresses to death typically within one year of onset.

questions.question: How does Lewy body dementia present?
questions.answer: Lewy body dementia presents with fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, REM sleep behavior disorder, autonomic dysfunction, sensitivity to antipsychotics, and cognitive decline with prominent attention and visuospatial deficits.

questions.question: How does vascular dementia present?
questions.answer: Vascular dementia presents with stepwise cognitive decline, executive dysfunction, gait disturbance, emotional lability, history of strokes or vascular risk factors, and cognitive deficits correlating with vascular lesions on imaging.

questions.question: How does frontotemporal dementia present?
questions.answer: Frontotemporal dementia presents with early personality and behavioral changes, disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive behaviors, language difficulties (progressive aphasia variants), and relative preservation of memory initially.

questions.question: How does moyamoya disease present?
questions.answer: Moyamoya disease presents with recurrent strokes or TIAs, seizures, headaches, cognitive decline, involuntary movements, and symptoms often triggered by hyperventilation or crying in children.

questions.question: How does syringomyelia present?
questions.answer: Syringomyelia presents with dissociated sensory loss (loss of pain and temperature with preserved touch), muscle weakness and atrophy in hands, scoliosis, spasticity in legs, and symptoms progress slowly over years.

questions.question: How does spinal cord injury present?
questions.answer: Spinal cord injury presents with sudden loss of motor and sensory function below injury level, loss of bowel and bladder control, spasticity or flaccidity depending on stage, autonomic dysfunction, and completeness varies.

questions.question: How does cavernous malformation present?
questions.answer: Cavernous malformation presents with seizures, headaches, focal neurological deficits, hemorrhage symptoms, or may be asymptomatic and discovered incidentally, with symptoms depending on location and bleeding episodes.

questions.question: How does arteriovenous malformation present?
questions.answer: Arteriovenous malformation presents with seizures, headaches, progressive neurological deficits, intracranial hemorrhage, pulsatile tinnitus, or cardiac symptoms from steal phenomenon, often diagnosed in young adults.

questions.question: How does pseudotumor cerebri present?
questions.answer: Pseudotumor cerebri presents with headache, transient visual obscurations, double vision, pulsatile tinnitus, papilledema on examination, and risk of permanent vision loss if untreated, typically in obese women of childbearing age.

questions.question: How does acoustic neuroma present?
questions.answer: Acoustic neuroma presents with gradual unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo, balance problems, facial numbness or weakness (in larger tumors), and symptoms progress slowly over months to years.

questions.question: How does pituitary tumor present?
questions.answer: Pituitary tumor presents with hormonal effects (amenorrhea, galactorrhea, acromegaly, Cushing's), mass effects (headache, visual field defects), or may be incidental finding, symptoms depending on tumor type and size.

questions.question: How does glioblastoma present?
questions.answer: Glioblastoma presents with rapidly progressive symptoms including headaches, seizures, focal neurological deficits, personality changes, cognitive decline, and symptoms worsen over weeks to months due to aggressive growth.

questions.question: How does meningioma present?
questions.answer: Meningioma presents with slowly progressive symptoms including headaches, seizures, focal deficits, personality changes, or may be asymptomatic and found incidentally, symptoms depending on location and size.

questions.question: How does oligodendroglioma present?
questions.answer: Oligodendroglioma presents with seizures (most common initial symptom), headaches, focal neurological deficits, personality changes, and typically slower progression than glioblastoma with better prognosis.

questions.question: How does medulloblastoma present?
questions.answer: Medulloblastoma presents in children with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (morning headache, vomiting), cerebellar signs (ataxia, coordination problems), and cranial nerve palsies.

questions.question: How does ependymoma present?
questions.answer: Ependymoma presents with symptoms of hydrocephalus (headache, vomiting, lethargy), focal neurological deficits, seizures, and symptoms depend on location (posterior fossa common in children, spine in adults).

questions.question: How does neurocysticercosis present?
questions.answer: Neurocysticercosis presents with seizures (most common), headaches, focal neurological deficits, hydrocephalus, cognitive changes, and symptoms vary based on number, location, and stage of cysts.

questions.question: How does cerebral vasculitis present?
questions.answer: Cerebral vasculitis presents with headaches, cognitive decline, stroke or TIA, seizures, encephalopathy, and symptoms may be acute or subacute with variable neurological manifestations.

questions.question: How does Miller Fisher syndrome present?
questions.answer: Miller Fisher syndrome presents with classic triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia, along with facial weakness and sensory symptoms, typically following infection.

questions.question: How does cauda equina syndrome present?
questions.answer: Cauda equina syndrome presents with severe low back pain, bilateral leg weakness, saddle anesthesia, bowel and bladder dysfunction (urinary retention), and constitutes a surgical emergency.

questions.question: How does locked-in syndrome present?
questions.answer: Locked-in syndrome presents with quadriplegia, anarthria (inability to speak), preserved consciousness and cognition, vertical eye movements and blinking intact, and results from ventral pontine damage.

questions.question: How does akinetic mutism present?
questions.answer: Akinetic mutism presents with lack of spontaneous movement and speech, appearing awake but unresponsive, may track with eyes, responds minimally to stimuli, and results from bilateral frontal or thalamic lesions.

questions.question: How does central pontine myelinolysis present?
questions.answer: Central pontine myelinolysis presents with dysarthria, dysphagia, quadriparesis, altered consciousness, movement disorders, and occurs days after rapid sodium correction in chronically hyponatremic patients.

questions.question: How does Wilson's disease present?
questions.answer: Wilson's disease presents with hepatic symptoms (jaundice, cirrhosis), neurological symptoms (tremor, dystonia, dysarthria, personality changes), Kayser-Fleischer rings, and psychiatric manifestations, typically in adolescence or young adulthood.

questions.question: How does neurosarcoidosis present?
questions.answer: Neurosarcoidosis presents with cranial neuropathies (especially facial palsy), aseptic meningitis, seizures, hydrocephalus, cognitive changes, peripheral neuropathy, and may involve any part of nervous system.

questions.question: How does primary progressive aphasia present?
questions.answer: Primary progressive aphasia presents with isolated progressive language dysfunction (word-finding difficulty, grammar errors, comprehension problems) as initial symptom, with relatively preserved memory and other cognitive functions initially.

questions.question: How does corticobasal degeneration present?
questions.answer: Corticobasal degeneration presents with asymmetric rigidity and apraxia, alien limb phenomenon, dystonia, myoclonus, cognitive decline, and poor response to levodopa.

questions.question: How does fatal familial insomnia present?
questions.answer: Fatal familial insomnia presents with progressive insomnia, autonomic dysfunction, hallucinations, rapid weight loss, dementia, and is invariably fatal within months to years.

questions.question: How does Rasmussen's encephalitis present?
questions.answer: Rasmussen's encephalitis presents in children with frequent seizures, progressive hemiparesis, cognitive decline, and inflammation of one cerebral hemisphere.

questions.question: How does stiff person syndrome present?
questions.answer: Stiff person syndrome presents with progressive muscle stiffness and rigidity (especially trunk and legs), painful muscle spasms triggered by stimuli, exaggerated startle response, and impaired mobility.

questions.question: How does Lambert-Eaton syndrome present?
questions.answer: Lambert-Eaton syndrome presents with proximal muscle weakness (legs more than arms), autonomic symptoms (dry mouth, constipation), reduced reflexes that improve after exercise, and often paraneoplastic (small cell lung cancer).

questions.question: How does neuromyelitis optica present?
questions.answer: Neuromyelitis optica presents with severe optic neuritis (bilateral or sequential), longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis, area postrema syndrome (nausea, vomiting, hiccups), and positive aquaporin-4 antibodies.

questions.question: How does cerebellar ataxia present?
questions.answer: Cerebellar ataxia presents with wide-based gait, incoordination, intention tremor, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, nystagmus, scanning speech, and symptoms bilateral and symmetric.

questions.question: How does spinocerebellar ataxia present?
questions.answer: Spinocerebellar ataxia presents with progressive cerebellar ataxia, dysarthria, dysphagia, eye movement abnormalities, pyramidal signs, and additional features vary by specific genetic subtype.

questions.question: How does Friedreich's ataxia present?
questions.answer: Friedreich's ataxia presents in childhood/adolescence with progressive ataxia, areflexia, sensory loss, dysarthria, scoliosis, pes cavus, cardiomyopathy, and diabetes mellitus.

questions.question: How does cerebellar degeneration present?
questions.answer: Cerebellar degeneration presents with progressive ataxia, dysarthria, nystagmus, incoordination, and may be hereditary, paraneoplastic, toxic, or idiopathic in etiology.

questions.question: How does olivopontocerebellar atrophy present?
questions.answer: Olivopontocerebellar atrophy presents with cerebellar ataxia, parkinsonism, autonomic dysfunction, pyramidal signs, and now classified under multiple system atrophy cerebellar type.

questions.question: How does primary lateral sclerosis present?
questions.answer: Primary lateral sclerosis presents with slowly progressive spasticity and weakness (legs more than arms), hyperreflexia, pseudobulbar affect, preserved sensation, and no lower motor neuron signs.

questions.question: How does progressive muscular atrophy present?
questions.answer: Progressive muscular atrophy presents with progressive muscle weakness and atrophy, fasciculations, preserved sensation, pure lower motor neuron signs, and better prognosis than ALS.

questions.question: How does Kennedy's disease present?
questions.answer: Kennedy's disease presents in males with slowly progressive proximal weakness, bulbar symptoms, fasciculations, gynecomastia, reduced fertility, and X-linked inheritance affecting CAG repeat in androgen receptor gene.

questions.question: How does Isaac's syndrome present?
questions.answer: Isaac's syndrome presents with continuous muscle fiber activity causing muscle stiffness, cramps, fasciculations, myokymia, excessive sweating, and symptoms persist during sleep.

questions.question: How does multifocal motor neuropathy present?
questions.answer: Multifocal motor neuropathy presents with asymmetric progressive weakness affecting individual nerves (often wrist/finger drop), fasciculations, no sensory loss, preserved reflexes, and responds to immunotherapy.

questions.question: How does chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy present?
questions.answer: Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy presents with progressive or relapsing symmetric proximal and distal weakness, sensory symptoms, areflexia, and symptoms evolving over at least 2 months.

questions.question: How does brachial plexus injury present?
questions.answer: Brachial plexus injury presents with shoulder and arm pain, weakness, sensory loss, and reflex changes in pattern determined by which nerve roots/trunks affected, often from trauma or traction.

questions.question: How does carpal tunnel syndrome present?
questions.answer: Carpal tunnel syndrome presents with numbness and tingling in thumb, index, middle fingers, and radial half of ring finger, nocturnal symptoms, weakness of thumb opposition, and positive Phalen's and Tinel's signs.

questions.question: How does ulnar nerve entrapment present?
questions.answer: Ulnar nerve entrapment presents with numbness and tingling in little and ring fingers, hand weakness (especially intrinsic muscles), claw hand deformity, and symptoms often at elbow (cubital tunnel) or wrist (Guyon's canal).

questions.question: How does radial nerve palsy present?
questions.answer: Radial nerve palsy presents with wrist drop, inability to extend fingers at MCP joints, numbness over dorsum of first web space, and commonly from compression (Saturday night palsy) or trauma.

questions.question: How does peroneal nerve injury present?
questions.answer: Peroneal nerve injury presents with foot drop, inability to dorsiflex or evert foot, high-stepping gait, numbness over dorsum of foot, and commonly from fibular head compression or knee trauma.

questions.question: How does sciatic nerve pain present?
questions.answer: Sciatic nerve pain presents with radiating pain from lower back through buttock down posterior leg, numbness, tingling, weakness in leg or foot, and pain worsened by sitting or Valsalva maneuvers.

questions.question: How does diabetic neuropathy present?
questions.answer: Diabetic neuropathy presents with symmetric distal sensory loss (glove-and-stocking), burning pain, numbness, loss of protective sensation leading to foot ulcers, autonomic dysfunction, and rarely acute painful neuropathy.

questions.question: How does alcoholic neuropathy present?
questions.answer: Alcoholic neuropathy presents with distal sensory loss, burning pain in feet, muscle weakness and atrophy, autonomic dysfunction, and symptoms correlate with chronic heavy alcohol use and nutritional deficiencies.

questions.question: How does chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy present?
questions.answer: Chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy presents with distal numbness and tingling, burning pain, cold sensitivity, loss of proprioception, difficulty with fine motor tasks, and symptoms may improve or persist after treatment completion.

questions.question: How does vitamin B12 deficiency neuropathy present?
questions.answer: Vitamin B12 deficiency neuropathy presents with paresthesias in hands and feet, loss of proprioception and vibration sense, ataxia, weakness, cognitive changes, and may include subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord.

questions.question: How does small fiber neuropathy present?
questions.answer: Small fiber neuropathy presents with burning pain, dysesthesias, allodynia, temperature sensation loss, autonomic symptoms (dry eyes, orthostatic hypotension), and normal nerve conduction studies despite symptoms.

questions.question: How does amyloid neuropathy present?
questions.answer: Amyloid neuropathy presents with progressive painful sensory and autonomic neuropathy, carpal tunnel syndrome, cardiac involvement, and may be hereditary (ATTR) or acquired (AL amyloidosis).

questions.question: How does vasculitic neuropathy present?
questions.answer: Vasculitic neuropathy presents with acute or subacute painful asymmetric neuropathy (mononeuritis multiplex), stepwise progression, constitutional symptoms, and associated systemic vasculitis features.

questions.question: How does HIV-associated neuropathy present?
