questions.answer: HIV-associated neuropathy presents with distal symmetric painful sensory neuropathy, burning feet, loss of ankle reflexes, and may be from HIV itself or antiretroviral medications.

questions.question: How does Lyme disease neuropathy present?
questions.answer: Lyme disease neuropathy presents with facial palsy, radiculoneuropathy with pain, mononeuropathy multiplex, or distal polyneuropathy, occurring weeks to months after tick bite.

questions.question: How does post-herpetic neuralgia present?
questions.answer: Post-herpetic neuralgia presents with persistent burning, stabbing, or shooting pain in dermatomal distribution after shingles rash heals, allodynia, and pain lasting months to years.

questions.question: How does complex regional pain syndrome present?
questions.answer: Complex regional pain syndrome presents with severe disproportionate pain, sensory changes, vasomotor changes (temperature, color, sweating), motor dysfunction, trophic changes, and triggered by injury or surgery.

questions.question: How does phantom limb pain present?
questions.answer: Phantom limb pain presents with painful sensations perceived in amputated limb, cramping, burning, or shooting pain, telescoping phenomenon, and triggered by various stimuli or stress.

questions.question: How does muscular dystrophy present?
questions.answer: Muscular dystrophy presents with progressive muscle weakness (pattern varies by type), muscle wasting, contractures, difficulty with mobility, pseudohypertrophy of calves in some types, and elevated creatine kinase.

questions.question: How does Duchenne muscular dystrophy present?
questions.answer: Duchenne muscular dystrophy presents in early childhood with proximal muscle weakness, Gowers' sign, calf pseudohypertrophy, progressive weakness leading to wheelchair dependence by teens, cardiomyopathy, and cognitive impairment.

questions.question: How does Becker muscular dystrophy present?
questions.answer: Becker muscular dystrophy presents with later onset and milder course than Duchenne, proximal weakness, calf hypertrophy, cardiomyopathy, ambulatory into adulthood, and variable severity.

questions.question: How does myotonic dystrophy present?
questions.answer: Myotonic dystrophy presents with myotonia (delayed muscle relaxation), distal weakness, facial weakness (hatchet face), cataracts, cardiac conduction defects, endocrine abnormalities, and multisystem involvement.

questions.question: How does facioscapulohumeral dystrophy present?
questions.answer: Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy presents with facial weakness (difficulty closing eyes, whistling), scapular winging, shoulder weakness, foot drop, and asymmetric pattern with slow progression.

questions.question: How does limb-girdle muscular dystrophy present?
questions.answer: Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy presents with progressive weakness of pelvic or shoulder girdle muscles, difficulty climbing stairs or lifting arms, calf hypertrophy sometimes, cardiac and respiratory involvement in some types.

questions.question: How does inflammatory myopathy present?
questions.answer: Inflammatory myopathy presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness, elevated creatine kinase, muscle pain or tenderness, difficulty rising from chair or climbing stairs, and may have systemic features.

questions.question: How does rhabdomyolysis present?
questions.answer: Rhabdomyolysis presents with muscle pain, weakness, swelling, dark urine (myoglobinuria), elevated creatine kinase (often >10,000), and risk of acute kidney injury from myoglobin.

questions.question: How does mitochondrial myopathy present?
questions.answer: Mitochondrial myopathy presents with exercise intolerance, muscle weakness, ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, lactic acidosis with exercise, and often multisystem involvement including cardiac and neurological features.

questions.question: How does periodic paralysis present?
questions.answer: Periodic paralysis presents with episodic weakness lasting hours to days, triggered by rest after exercise, carbohydrate meals, or stress, preserved consciousness, and may be hypokalemic, hyperkalemic, or normokalemic.

questions.question: How does hypokalemic periodic paralysis present?
questions.answer: Hypokalemic periodic paralysis presents with episodes of flaccid weakness during or after rest following exercise, triggered by carbohydrate-rich meals, low potassium during attacks, and spares respiratory and facial muscles.

questions.question: How does hyperkalemic periodic paralysis present?
questions.answer: Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis presents with brief episodes of weakness, myotonia between attacks, triggered by rest after exercise or potassium intake, elevated potassium during attacks, and earlier onset than hypokalemic form.

questions.question: How does paramyotonia congenita present?
questions.answer: Paramyotonia congenita presents with paradoxical myotonia (worsening with repeated activity), cold-induced stiffness and weakness, facial and hand involvement, and episodes triggered by cold exposure.

questions.question: How does myotonia congenita present?
questions.answer: Myotonia congenita presents with muscle stiffness improving with repeated activity (warm-up phenomenon), grip myotonia, muscle hypertrophy, and symptoms from childhood with autosomal dominant or recessive inheritance.

questions.question: How does critical illness myopathy present?
questions.answer: Critical illness myopathy presents in ICU patients with difficulty weaning from ventilator, diffuse muscle weakness, preserved sensation, elevated creatine kinase, and develops after sepsis, steroids, or neuromuscular blockade.

questions.question: How does critical illness polyneuropathy present?
questions.answer: Critical illness polyneuropathy presents in ICU with difficulty weaning from ventilator, distal weakness, sensory loss, reduced reflexes, and develops after sepsis or systemic inflammatory response syndrome.

questions.question: How does botulism present?
questions.answer: Botulism presents with descending paralysis starting with cranial nerves (diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, dilated pupils), progressing to limb and respiratory weakness, and no sensory or cognitive changes.

questions.question: How does tetanus present?
questions.answer: Tetanus presents with muscle rigidity and spasms, trismus (lockjaw), risus sardonicus (facial spasm), opisthotonos (arched back), dysphagia, and spasms triggered by minimal stimuli.

questions.question: How does rabies encephalitis present?
questions.answer: Rabies encephalitis presents with anxiety, confusion, agitation, hydrophobia (fear of water), aerophobia, hypersalivation, hallucinations, and progressive deterioration to coma and death.

questions.question: How does poliomyelitis present?
questions.answer: Poliomyelitis presents with fever, headache, stiff neck, asymmetric flaccid paralysis, muscle pain, fasciculations, and permanent paralysis in some cases, now rare due to vaccination.

questions.question: How does post-polio syndrome present?
questions.answer: Post-polio syndrome presents decades after polio with new muscle weakness, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, cold intolerance, and symptoms in previously affected and unaffected muscles.

questions.question: How does West Nile encephalitis present?
questions.answer: West Nile encephalitis presents with fever, headache, neck stiffness, confusion, tremors, muscle weakness, flaccid paralysis (like polio), seizures, and more severe in elderly or immunocompromised.

questions.question: How does Japanese encephalitis present?
questions.answer: Japanese encephalitis presents with fever, headache, altered mental status, seizures, parkinsonian features, flaccid paralysis, and high mortality and morbidity rates.

questions.question: How does tick-borne encephalitis present?
questions.answer: Tick-borne encephalitis presents with biphasic illness - initial flu-like symptoms, then after brief improvement neurological phase with meningitis, encephalitis, or meningoencephalitis.

questions.question: How does cerebral malaria present?
questions.answer: Cerebral malaria presents with altered consciousness, seizures, coma, fever, severe headache, and high mortality if untreated, occurs with Plasmodium falciparum infection.

questions.question: How does neurotoxoplasmosis present?
questions.answer: Neurotoxoplasmosis presents in immunocompromised with headache, confusion, focal neurological deficits, seizures, fever, and multiple ring-enhancing lesions on brain imaging.

questions.question: How does cryptococcal meningitis present?
questions.answer: Cryptococcal meningitis presents in immunocompromised with subacute headache, fever, altered mental status, neck stiffness, vision problems, and elevated intracranial pressure.

questions.question: How does tuberculous meningitis present?
questions.answer: Tuberculous meningitis presents with subacute onset of fever, headache, neck stiffness, confusion, cranial nerve palsies, and basal meningeal enhancement on imaging.

questions.question: How does neurosyphilis present?
questions.answer: Neurosyphilis presents variably with meningitis, stroke, cranial nerve palsies, tabes dorsalis (sensory ataxia, lightning pains), general paresis (dementia, personality changes), or may be asymptomatic.

questions.question: How does HIV encephalopathy present?
questions.answer: HIV encephalopathy presents with cognitive decline, motor slowing, behavioral changes, apathy, and progression to dementia if untreated, improved with antiretroviral therapy.

questions.question: How does progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy present?
questions.answer: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy presents in immunocompromised with subacute focal neurological deficits, cognitive decline, visual changes, weakness, and progressive multifocal demyelination from JC virus.

questions.question: How does subacute sclerosing panencephalitis present?
questions.answer: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis presents years after measles with behavioral changes, cognitive decline, myoclonic jerks, seizures, progressive deterioration to vegetative state, and is fatal.

questions.question: How does cytomegalovirus encephalitis present?
questions.answer: Cytomegalovirus encephalitis presents in immunocompromised with rapidly progressive confusion, decreased consciousness, seizures, focal deficits, and ventriculoencephalitis pattern on imaging.

questions.question: How does herpes simplex encephalitis present?
questions.answer: Herpes simplex encephalitis presents acutely with fever, headache, altered mental status, personality changes, seizures, focal deficits, and temporal lobe involvement on imaging.

questions.question: How does varicella zoster encephalitis present?
questions.answer: Varicella zoster encephalitis presents with altered mental status, focal deficits, seizures, and may occur with or without rash, in immunocompromised or elderly patients.

questions.question: How does enteroviral meningitis present?
questions.answer: Enteroviral meningitis presents in summer/fall with fever, headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, nausea, usually self-limited, more common in children, and most common cause of viral meningitis.

questions.question: How does bacterial meningitis in adults present?
questions.answer: Bacterial meningitis in adults presents acutely with fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, altered mental status, petechial rash (meningococcal), seizures, and constitutes medical emergency.

questions.question: How does bacterial meningitis in neonates present?
questions.answer: Bacterial meningitis in neonates presents with poor feeding, irritability, lethargy, fever or hypothermia, bulging fontanel, seizures, and may have subtle signs requiring high suspicion.

questions.question: How does viral meningitis present?
questions.answer: Viral meningitis presents with fever, headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, nausea, less severe than bacterial, usually self-limited, and cerebrospinal fluid shows lymphocytic pleocytosis.

questions.question: How does fungal meningitis present?
questions.answer: Fungal meningitis presents subacutely in immunocompromised with headache, fever, altered mental status, cranial nerve palsies, and requires prolonged antifungal treatment.

questions.question: How does aseptic meningitis present?
questions.answer: Aseptic meningitis presents with meningitis symptoms but negative bacterial cultures, caused by viruses, medications, autoimmune conditions, or other non-bacterial causes.

questions.question: How does carcinomatous meningitis present?
questions.answer: Carcinomatous meningitis presents with headache, cranial nerve palsies, radicular pain, altered mental status, and malignant cells in cerebrospinal fluid from leptomeningeal spread of cancer.

questions.question: How does spinal epidural abscess present?
questions.answer: Spinal epidural abscess presents with progressive back pain, fever, radicular pain, and rapidly progressive weakness, sensory loss, and bowel/bladder dysfunction, constituting surgical emergency.

questions.question: How does transverse myelitis present?
questions.answer: Transverse myelitis presents with acute or subacute bilateral motor weakness, sensory level, bowel and bladder dysfunction, back pain, and symptoms evolving over hours to days.

questions.question: How does acute flaccid myelitis present?
questions.answer: Acute flaccid myelitis presents in children with sudden onset of limb weakness, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, often after viral illness, affecting gray matter of spinal cord.

questions.question: How does spinal cord compression present?
questions.answer: Spinal cord compression presents with progressive back pain, weakness below level, sensory level, bowel/bladder dysfunction, and requires urgent diagnosis and treatment to prevent permanent damage.

questions.question: How does spinal cord infarction present?
questions.answer: Spinal cord infarction presents with sudden onset of weakness, sensory loss, and bowel/bladder dysfunction, often preceded by back pain, with anterior spinal artery syndrome most common.

questions.question: How does anterior spinal artery syndrome present?
questions.answer: Anterior spinal artery syndrome presents with sudden bilateral motor weakness, loss of pain and temperature sensation, preserved proprioception and vibration, and bowel/bladder dysfunction.

questions.question: How does central cord syndrome present?
questions.answer: Central cord syndrome presents after hyperextension injury with greater weakness in arms than legs, sensory loss with sacral sparing, bowel/bladder dysfunction, and typically in elderly with cervical spondylosis.

questions.question: How does Brown-Sequard syndrome present?
questions.answer: Brown-Sequard syndrome presents with ipsilateral motor weakness and proprioception loss, contralateral pain and temperature loss, from hemisection of spinal cord.

questions.question: How does conus medullaris syndrome present?
questions.answer: Conus medullaris syndrome presents with sudden onset of bilateral leg weakness, saddle anesthesia, severe bowel and bladder dysfunction, erectile dysfunction, and affects terminal spinal cord.

questions.question: How does cervical spondylotic myelopathy present?
questions.answer: Cervical spondylotic myelopathy presents with progressive hand clumsiness, gait difficulties, neck pain, upper motor neuron signs in legs, lower motor neuron signs in arms, and Lhermitte's sign.

questions.question: How does lumbar spinal stenosis present?
questions.answer: Lumbar spinal stenosis presents with neurogenic claudication (leg pain/weakness with walking, relieved by sitting or bending forward), back pain, and symptoms worse with extension.

questions.question: How does cervical radiculopathy present?
questions.answer: Cervical radiculopathy presents with neck pain radiating to arm in dermatomal pattern, sensory changes, weakness in specific myotome, reduced reflex, and symptoms with neck extension or rotation.

questions.question: How does lumbar radiculopathy present?
questions.answer: Lumbar radiculopathy presents with low back pain radiating down leg in dermatomal pattern, positive straight leg raise, sensory changes, weakness in specific myotome, and reduced reflex.

questions.question: How does herniated disc present?
questions.answer: Herniated disc presents with back or neck pain, radicular pain in dermatomal distribution, sensory changes, weakness, positive nerve tension signs, and symptoms with certain movements.

questions.question: How does spinal stenosis present?
questions.answer: Spinal stenosis presents with back pain, neurogenic claudication, bilateral leg symptoms, symptoms relieved with sitting or flexion, and worse with standing or extension.

questions.question: How does spondylolisthesis present?
questions.answer: Spondylolisthesis presents with low back pain, radicular symptoms if nerve compression, visible or palpable step-off, hamstring tightness, and mechanical back pain with activities.

questions.question: How does spinal cord tumor present?
questions.answer: Spinal cord tumor presents with progressive back pain (worse at night), motor and sensory deficits, bowel/bladder dysfunction, and symptoms depend on tumor location (intramedullary vs extramedullary).

questions.question: How does tethered cord syndrome present?
questions.answer: Tethered cord syndrome presents with back pain, leg weakness, sensory deficits, foot deformities, bowel/bladder problems, scoliosis, and symptoms worsen with growth or activity.

questions.question: How does spina bifida present?
questions.answer: Spina bifida presents with visible defect in spine, leg weakness and paralysis, bowel and bladder problems, hydrocephalus, orthopedic deformities, and severity varies by type (occulta vs myelomeningocele).

questions.question: How does arachnoiditis present?
questions.answer: Arachnoiditis presents with chronic severe back and leg pain, burning sensations, tingling, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder problems, and caused by inflammation of arachnoid membrane.

questions.question: How does empty sella syndrome present?
questions.answer: Empty sella syndrome presents with headaches, vision problems, endocrine dysfunction, or is asymptomatic incidental finding, with CSF filling sella turcica compressing pituitary.

questions.question: How does pineal cyst present?
questions.answer: Pineal cyst presents with headaches, Parinaud syndrome (vertical gaze palsy), hydrocephalus if large, or often asymptomatic incidental finding on imaging.

questions.question: How does colloid cyst present?
questions.answer: Colloid cyst presents with positional headaches, sudden severe headache, drop attacks, hydrocephalus symptoms, and can cause sudden death if blocks foramen of Monro.

questions.question: How does arachnoid cyst present?
questions.answer: Arachnoid cyst presents with headaches, seizures, developmental delays, hydrocephalus, focal deficits depending on location, or often asymptomatic incidental finding.

questions.question: How does dermoid cyst present?
questions.answer: Dermoid cyst presents with mass effect symptoms, seizures, may rupture causing chemical meningitis, and contains ectodermal elements (skin, hair follicles).

questions.question: How does epidermoid cyst present?
questions.answer: Epidermoid cyst presents with slowly progressive symptoms from mass effect, cranial nerve deficits, hydrocephalus, and pearl-like appearance on imaging.

questions.question: How does Rathke's cleft cyst present?
questions.answer: Rathke's cleft cyst presents with headaches, vision problems, endocrine dysfunction (hypopituitarism), or asymptomatic, located between pituitary lobes.

questions.question: How does craniopharyngioma present?
questions.answer: Craniopharyngioma presents with vision problems (bitemporal hemianopia), endocrine deficiencies (growth hormone, others), headaches, and more common in children but can occur at any age.

questions.question: How does choroid plexus papilloma present?
questions.answer: Choroid plexus papilloma presents with hydrocephalus from CSF overproduction, increased intracranial pressure symptoms, and most common in children.

questions.question: How does hemangioblastoma present?
questions.answer: Hemangioblastoma presents with cerebellar signs (ataxia, nystagmus), headache, polycythemia, and may be sporadic or associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease.

questions.question: How does vestibular schwannoma present?
questions.answer: Vestibular schwannoma presents with progressive unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo, balance problems, facial numbness (large tumors), and slow growth rate.

questions.question: How does spinal schwannoma present?
questions.answer: Spinal schwannoma presents with radicular pain, sensory changes, weakness, and symptoms develop gradually from nerve root compression.

questions.question: How does neurofibroma present?
questions.answer: Neurofibroma presents with soft cutaneous or subcutaneous masses, pain or tenderness, numbness if affecting nerve, and multiple lesions suggest neurofibromatosis type 1.

questions.question: How does ganglioglioma present?
questions.answer: Ganglioglioma presents with drug-resistant seizures, headaches, focal deficits, slow-growing tumor containing both neuronal and glial elements, and good prognosis with surgical resection.

questions.question: How does dysembryoplastic neuroepithelial tumor present?
questions.answer: Dysembryoplastic neuroepithelial tumor presents with seizures starting in childhood or adolescence, typically temporal lobe, benign slow-growing lesion, and excellent prognosis.

questions.question: How does central neurocytoma present?
questions.answer: Central neurocytoma presents with hydrocephalus symptoms (headache, nausea, vomiting), located in lateral ventricles, and has good prognosis with treatment.

questions.question: How does subependymoma present?
questions.answer: Subependymoma presents with hydrocephalus symptoms if blocking CSF flow, or often asymptomatic incidental finding, slow-growing benign tumor in ventricles.

questions.question: How does pilocytic astrocytoma present?
questions.answer: Pilocytic astrocytoma presents in children with cerebellar signs, hydrocephalus, vision problems if optic pathway, and has excellent prognosis with grade I designation.

questions.question: How does diffuse astrocytoma present?
questions.answer: Diffuse astrocytoma presents with seizures, headaches, focal deficits, grade II tumor with infiltrative growth, and tendency to progress to higher grade over time.

questions.question: How does anaplastic astrocytoma present?
questions.answer: Anaplastic astrocytoma presents with progressive neurological symptoms, seizures, headaches, focal deficits, grade III malignant tumor with more rapid growth than grade II.

questions.question: How does diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma present?
questions.answer: Diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma presents in children with cranial nerve palsies, ataxia, long tract signs, and has poor prognosis with infiltrative brainstem tumor.

questions.question: How does brain metastases present?
questions.answer: Brain metastases present with headaches, seizures, focal deficits, cognitive changes, multiple lesions typically at gray-white junction, and symptoms depend on location and number.

questions.question: How does leptomeningeal metastases present?
questions.answer: Leptomeningeal metastases present with headache, cranial nerve palsies, radicular pain, altered mental status, and malignant cells in CSF from spread along meninges.

questions.question: How does primary CNS lymphoma present?
questions.answer: Primary CNS lymphoma presents with cognitive changes, personality changes, headaches, focal deficits, may have multiple lesions, and more common in immunocompromised patients.

questions.question: How does germinoma present?
questions.answer: Germinoma presents in children/young adults with diabetes insipidus, vision problems, endocrine dysfunction, pineal or suprasellar location, and responds well to radiation.

questions.question: How does chordoma present?
questions.answer: Chordoma presents with progressive cranial nerve palsies, headaches, double vision, and arises from notochordal remnants at skull base or sacrum.

questions.question: How does radiation necrosis present?
questions.answer: Radiation necrosis presents months to years after radiation with symptoms similar to tumor recurrence, focal deficits, seizures, edema, and difficult to distinguish from recurrent tumor on imaging.
